review_preview: We arrived in Madrid for our first time around dinner time so we stopped by La Mi Venta because it was close to our hotel.  We did not go inside at all, but they had a nice outdoor seating area where we were quickly greeted...
review_full: We arrived in Madrid for our first time around dinner time so we stopped by La Mi Venta because it was close to our hotel. We did not go inside at all, but they had a nice outdoor seating area where we were quickly greeted by our waiter, Miguel. He brought us warm, delicious bread to start and made some recommendations for the rest of the menu. On his recommendation we started with the assorted appetizer of cured meats, which was delicious. Apparently their specialty is meat, but we were in the mood for paella so we ordered that instead. The menu made a note that it would be about a 40 minute wait which we were fine with, but they even brought us some additional small plates of veggies to share while we waited, which was unexpected, but appreciated. The paella came out and Miguel did a beautiful job of plating it tableside for us, and everything was delicious! For dessert we ordered the passion fruit soup which was refreshing and tasty, and the chocolate mousse. We also ordered a coffee with brandy and Miguel came out again and made a lovely presentation of warming the brandy by pouring hot water into one glass and using another to steam it, which I had never seen before, but made for an entertaining aspect of our dinner. Overall, I would definitely recommend La Mi Venta, and our waiter, Miguel, was extremely helpful with recommendations and his English was excellent.

I suspect it is a place that polarises opinions more than most, so that what appeals to some diners may well not work for others.

review_preview: On a 4 day break in Atocha Madrid - did research beforehand and had eaten well. This lunch however was something else - in a seriously good way. The restaurant is off the normal tourist track but worth the detour. Deceptively small from the outside...
review_full: On a 4 day break in Atocha Madrid - did research beforehand and had eaten well. This lunch however was something else - in a seriously good way. The restaurant is off the normal tourist track but worth the detour. Deceptively small from the outside the interior is fresh, modern, classic and comfortable. We sat at the bar for a glass (read bottle) of wine and were offered a number of tapas to try in succession - little sausage and green pepper burgers, a soup which we believe was cocidado stock, a confit potato tortilla - all of which enhanced our appetites for lunch proper. So lunch - smoked sardines on a bed of courgette and tomato with fennel oil. Bacalao - baked salt cod onions and potato. White tuna salad. And the house speciality - baked cream. Try as we do - and we've been discussing this since we finished - we cannot rate one of these dishes over the other. They were all superb and by far some of the best we've had since we arrived, which is saying something. The staff too were welcoming and friendly and we could not have felt more at home. Our Spanish is limited so special mention for the chef's daughter who kindly translated our praises to the chef (Gloria). The name of the restaurant I think means 'taste of heaven' and without a doubt it certainty is. This restaurant deserves attention. We loved it and you would too. If we could give this more than 5 stars we would.

title_review: A pleasant surprise in an unassuming spot
review_preview: My partner and I discovered Sabe a Gloria unexpectedly when we were strolling around looking for dinner shortly after arriving at Madrid from Copenhagen. It was a pleasant surprise - high quality tapas (the beef jerky/jamon was fantastic and the sardines one, over a bed...
review_full: My partner and I discovered Sabe a Gloria unexpectedly when we were strolling around looking for dinner shortly after arriving at Madrid from Copenhagen. It was a pleasant surprise - high quality tapas (the beef jerky/jamon was fantastic and the sardines one, over a bed of tomatoes and zucchini, drenched in flavourful olive oil and fragrant peppercorns). It was so simple. The people are very friendly and courteous. But the highlight of the meal was the arroz marinera (not sure of the name but it’s the seafood one - the other one has duck in it). It was served really hot in a cast-iron pot. The flavours just exploded in my mouth. The people there would happily guide you what to order. I would recommend this place for a no-frills dinner, also good for first-timers in the city.

review_full: A beautiful, intimate, unique dining experience in the Unico Hotel in the Salamanca barrio of Madrid. The food presentation is a visual piece of art with each course displaying the creativity of Chef Freixa. We opted for the "experience menu" which is about 20 courses although you stop counting after the first few. The wine list is extensive, as one would expect, and the service highly efficient. There are little details that stand out like Chef Freixa visiting your table to talk about what he will be serving that evening and to adjust the menu for any food allergies, etc., or the bread which comes from his father's bakery in Catalonia. The food is more of classic combinations with lots of creativity. There is no dish that totally stands out as being a wow dish though they were all very good with interesting combination of flavours.

title_review: Good food but probably not 2 Michelin stars
review_preview: Had dinner here with 8 others, seated in a private area.  The whole restaurant is very quiet with little atmosphere, although this helped the conversation.Food was good.  We had a set menu pre-selected by our host and it was good.  The best dish was...
review_full: Had dinner here with 8 others, seated in a private area. The whole restaurant is very quiet with little atmosphere, although this helped the conversation. Food was good. We had a set menu pre-selected by our host and it was good. The best dish was the cod "done the Ramon Freixa way". The other excellent dish was a risotto with swordfish and black pudding - weird mix but excellent taste. The wine was excellent, service very proficient and invisible (which is good). As per other comments, the crockery was lovely Limoges porcelain. All in all nothing to complain about. I don't know the cost as I was with a group but there was nothing bad to report whatsoever. That said, it was not the best meal in my life, and perhaps I'd expected more from such a well rated establishment.

title_review: Very good, but not truly great
review_preview: We opted for the 80 euro tasting menu in this small restaurant, its design an ambitious and largely successful mixture of old and modern. Despite other reviews here, service was excellent from the small fleet of olive jacketed, blue trousered young waiters. Lunch turned out...
review_full: We opted for the 80 euro tasting menu in this small restaurant, its design an ambitious and largely successful mixture of old and modern. Despite other reviews here, service was excellent from the small fleet of olive jacketed, blue trousered young waiters.  Lunch turned out to be some seven or so courses of which the two highlights were the tomatoes and the meat courses. Sublime. But others didn't work quite so well, with mixtures of flavours where one was too delicate to balance the strength of the other. For this money i expect to have my socks blown off, and when i left they were still on.  For guidance, the tasting menus seem the way to go; a la carte will probably cost you more for less. The wine list is good and modestly priced as is common in Spain - we had an excellent albariño recommended by the sommelier for 25 euros. Expect to get out for 100-150 euros a head, depending on how bonkers you want to go. Unmissable? No. But certainly among Madrid's finer establishments.

title_review: Was a No-Brainer 5 Star Review Until...
review_preview: After an amazing day of sightseeing in 90 degree heat we were done and exhausted. Our reservation wasn't until 7:30 but we gave it a shot and asked the owner if we can sit down, have a drink and rest a bit until our reservation....
review_full: After an amazing day of sightseeing in 90 degree heat we were done and exhausted. Our reservation wasn't until 7:30 but we gave it a shot and asked the owner if we can sit down, have a drink and rest a bit until our reservation. He said no problem! The owner couldn't have been more gracious and hospitable. It was my wife's birthday and he didn't forget.  We had a few cold ones, took some pictures, then proceeded downstairs to my requested dining area. We had the male waiter who was fine... until the main course.  We went with all his recommendations. For myself he recommended the meats and I mistakenly ordered a T Bone steak for 46.30 Euros. He highly recommended it. When it arrived (look at picture) it was bloody red. I ordered medium. It came back a second time and it was still too rare. I asked if he can make it medium. I then heard him mumble something inappropriate. Clearly noticeable and unprofessional. It was really too bad because the night was perfect so far. The 3rd time it came back very well done; quite purposely I'm sure.  To an extent, this ruined what would have been a perfect dining experience. They brought out a nice birthday desert and after-dinner drinks which was nice, and the waiter gave himself a nice 20% tip (first and only time that happened during 12 days in Portugal and Spain), and that was that.  With all this said, I want to thank the owner for his gracious hospitality. It is truly a lovely restaurant.

Staff were friendly and helpful but cant understand the good reviews. We had to laugh at the experience to stop us from crying.

review_preview: This Michelin two star is not to be missed if you are looking for the pinnacle of refined flavors. This is not a place to go to eat but rather to taste. This place bills itself as an experience and it is. The flavors are...
review_full: This Michelin two star is not to be missed if you are looking for the pinnacle of refined flavors. This is not a place to go to eat but rather to taste. This place bills itself as an experience and it is. The flavors are orchestrated into a dance to stimulate every part of the palate.  We just came from Berlin where we had a truly great meal at Fischers Fritz (see my review.) The food at Fritz was flawless and created a great meal. Ramon Freixa is in a different realm from this. This is not about a flawlessly executed meal, which it is, but creating an art form of tasting surprise. With Fritz we could recognize everything before we ate it, here each bite was a discovery and a surprise. Nothing could be inferred from the shape or size, nothing hinted as to what was inside.  We chose the Experience Menu which was the medium size meal for 80Euro. Often the amuse bouche can be the most inventive flavorful part of the meal. Not the case here. Although the bread was outrageous and the silver foil wrapped foie de sardine was one flavor after another in one bite, there was much much more to come. Both in the presentation, small pieces of flat black pottery as part of the theme, and the multitude of small dishes the chef pays homage to the high art of Japanese Kaiseki. Spring mushrooms in a form that resembles a piece of a sushi roll for example, but tastes nothing like what it looks like, with a completely new and fresh palate. Only the tiny drop of wasabi as one of seven different flavored drops accompanying the fish tartare appetizer, hinted of Japan.  The wine paring of 40Euro brought six different glasses of wine, each perfectly paired with the course. Each glass complementing both the food and adding to the previous wine. We ordered The Experience and we recieved it beyond what we could have imagined. If you have the time for a full show it is well worth the price.

title_review: Giving it 3 stars, but it was anything but average
review_preview: Firstly the restaurant itself was a beautiful space. It was a gorgeous day and the room was well lit both naturally and internally. The table for 2 was huge but that added to the sense of theatre. The chef did come and take our order....
review_full: Firstly the restaurant itself was a beautiful space. It was a gorgeous day and the room was well lit both naturally and internally. The table for 2 was huge but that added to the sense of theatre. The chef did come and take our order. when we told him we had tickets for Real Madrid he recommended we take the menu but one dish less than the experience. It was nice to meet the chef and he did ask if there was anything we didn't like. My wife felt adventurous and said she'd eat most things but when the shellfish starter came I got most of it! You cannot fault the cooking or the ingredients and some of the flavour explosions were quite amazing the way they developed in the mouth, but it just didn't do it for me. I can totally see why it would get 5 stars but for me not knowing what I was getting and then not being totally happy with what I received left me slightly underwhelmed. As I said there were some true highlights but there were also some courses which we couldn't quite work out, i.e. where was the flavour connection between the dishes (each course is split into 3 elements for the diner). It seems almost unfair to give 3 stars especially as the service was also very nice and the accompanying wines well chosen, but it was very expensive and I guess I expected more; although for execution of the ingredients it cannot be faulted I was more often questioning why more than enjoying the combinations.

title_review: One of the best meals of my life; a love affair
review_preview: Okay, I looked them up and could not find them listed with Michelin stars. So the Michelin people have missed the boat. I have eaten in 3-star Michelin restaurants, and I am telling you that this restaurant is 3 stars. Dined there with 3 friends...
review_full: Okay, I looked them up and could not find them listed with Michelin stars. So the Michelin people have missed the boat. I have eaten in 3-star Michelin restaurants, and I am telling you that this restaurant is 3 stars. Dined there with 3 friends and it was so amazing that I am taking my boyfriend back there in october for his birthday. We each had a different menu because of food allergies and preferences from "The Experience" menu. The courses and paired wines were so amazing that we kept asking what each thing was and the names of the wine. When we left the waiter gave each of us an envelope and inside was a beautifully printed menu of what we ate for each course and what wine we had. That meal has become a love affair.

review_preview: Not only my favorite meal of the trip, but probably a top 10 meal of all time for me.Against my wife's request I opted for the Diverxo 1 tasting menu rather than the tasting menu that was a little smaller. Diverxo 1 was the...
review_full: Not only my favorite meal of the trip, but probably a top 10 meal of all time for me. Against my wife's request I opted for the Diverxo 1 tasting menu rather than the tasting menu that was a little smaller. Diverxo 1 was the 3rd largest of the 4 tasting menus offered. I didn't know what to expect since the restaurant combines chinese and spanish cuisine. There were a few items that were too extreme for my wife so I had to eat them (ie hot and sour soup w special noodles - baby eels, fried duck tongues, and squid heads with strawberries). The best bites were some type of oxtail pastry type thing topped with baby eels which was the first course, won ton/dumpling with a cracker, and ox which came as a thick narrow strip steak. I could also eat those fried duck tongues by the bag. So good. Monkfish was also very rich and good. Our reservation was at 10 and we weren't out of there until after 1. If I had to do it over again I would get the 2nd option tasting menu. The 3rd was just way too much food. I can't imagine the Chef David tasting menu which is the 4th option. Service was great and it was real nice talking to the wife of the chef (owner). Just a very good, very rich meal and one that I won't be forgetting anytime soon.

review_preview: I made a reservation at Diverxo for my friend's birthday and was really looking forward to trying out this 2 Michelin star restaurant. I unfortunately think my expectations were too high. I would give this a 3.5 stars if I could. The concept in the...
review_full: I made a reservation at Diverxo for my friend's birthday and was really looking forward to trying out this 2 Michelin star restaurant. I unfortunately think my expectations were too high. I would give this a 3.5 stars if I could. The concept in the decor and menu were a bit strange. On the tables, were metal contraptions with words that were describing the food. The menu was something that seemed more like modern poetry - but not something that would be understood by the average person. Our meal started out well with some excellent starters. The plates were flavorful, beautiful and highly inventive. As the meal progressed though, the service really started to wane - our server was having a difficult time explaining some of the courses which left us trying to figure out what we were eating. We actually had to have the manager come over to explain a dish again. When they poured water for us, they splashed it all over the table and didn't seem to notice. Doing this with water was one thing, but then when they did it with the wine as well that was just not right. The servers seemed inexperienced. At a restaurant of this caliber, we just expected better. The main courses were not very memorable. The desserts were beautiful and good but not great. We had been to El Club Allard a few nights prior to coming to Diverxo which was just a much better meal all around. I would recommend Diverxo since I think that the food is quite good and inventive, but the service and overall experience was not what we would have expected from a 2 Michelin star restaurant.

title_review: Mind-blowing food, good atmosphere- worth a splurge
review_preview: My husband and I had a wonderful meal at Diverxo last week during our Madrid trip.  We had 9 courses, no additions, which was a little over $300 with tip.  Obviously this was a splurge, but we felt it was worth it.  The presentation of...
review_full: My husband and I had a wonderful meal at Diverxo last week during our Madrid trip. We had 9 courses, no additions, which was a little over $300 with tip. Obviously this was a splurge, but we felt it was worth it. The presentation of each dish was unique and highly choreographed to go with the texture and type of course, and we were blown away by some of the items (truffle-oil dim sum with ox meat, rib meat raviolli with tamarind foam...crazy good), and impressed with all of them. The only issue we had was that we experienced some negative service due to (we think) 2 things. First, though we're in our mid/late 20's, we look younger and often feel that we don't always get the best service based on that, which is unfortunate, but we usually don't feel like there's much recourse other than in the size of the tip we give (try to be generous anyway though most of the time!). The other issue was that we didn't order anything to drink. Given that this was a very big, once in a lifetime sort of experience, we didn't want to have the wrong kind of wine or drink that might muddy the taste of the incredible dishes. We were there for the food and while we do enjoy wine with dinner on occasion, we didn't feel that it was necessary in this instance, and in fact, that it might take away from the food. I think that the combination of our age, our choice not to order a drink, (and the VIP-looking group that was sharing our waiter), led to patchy service. We literally sat there for 30 min. after being given an appetizer of edamame, but we hadn't seen a menu or anything. I was disappointed in this, but once we actually got served, they were polite and accomodating. Anyway, definitely worth a visit, the food alone is worth the price!

review_preview: One of Madrid's most prominent restaurants is hidden behind the Unico hotel - you actually have to walk around the hotel itself to find a small garden with the restaurant entrance. Inside, the restaurant is beautifully designed with a very laid-back and calm ambience, reflected...
review_full: One of Madrid's most prominent restaurants is hidden behind the Unico hotel - you actually have to walk around the hotel itself to find a small garden with the restaurant entrance. Inside, the restaurant is beautifully designed with a very laid-back and calm ambience, reflected in the staff's attentive and discreet service. Chef Freixa makes food that I would characterize as restrained and elegant - most plates are an interplay between subtle flavours complementing each other, not the big bold stuff you'll find in some other prominent restaurants. Basically, every single plate worked well out of 25, which is quite impressive - and the concept allows for some genuinely surprising combinations, like the one where you have beef, mortadella, nectarine, truffle, sea urchin and blackberry all on one plate, and it tastes beautifully. One word of warning, though: Don't go for the big 25-moments Homage menu unless you're really hungry!

review_preview: If you are into trying innovative cuisine with a Catalon flair this is a wonderful choice for a special meal in Madrid. Situated on a quiet street in the Hotel Unico in Salamanca, the restaurant has a lovely setting and an attentive yet unobtrusive staff....
review_full: If you are into trying innovative cuisine with a Catalon flair this is a wonderful choice for a special meal in Madrid. Situated on a quiet street in the Hotel Unico in Salamanca, the restaurant has a lovely setting and an attentive yet unobtrusive staff. Well priced and varied wine list with an excellent young sommelier. We chose to have one of the several prix fixe options and we already were served an amuse bouche and a selection of innovative "snacks" before our first appetizer appeared. Peas, asparagus and cod were followed by a scallop with artichokes along with a bone marrow flan and aloe vera with umami. Roasted garlic-onion pudding and amazing white beans with sausage were another highlight. Main courses of delightful servings of perfectly prepared fish and beef cheek. The evening closed with a variety of sweets, my favorite being a tiny lavender panacottta on honey cake. We read mixed reviews in our various research, but honestly cannot understand how anyone would not thoroughly enjoy an evening spent here. They have clearly earned their two Michelin stars.

review_preview: Ramon took our order and asked what we liked and did not like. The tasting menu was an adventure and paired with wines for each course. For the €90 menu with €40 wine pairing not outrageous by gourmet restaurant standards.The dining room is sleek...
review_full: Ramon took our order and asked what we liked and did not like. The tasting menu was an adventure and paired with wines for each course. For the €90 menu with €40 wine pairing not outrageous by gourmet restaurant standards. The dining room is sleek and modern, with high style design everywhere. Inside a boutique hotel. Service was outstanding, Very quiet and professional, but friendly. They carefully explained each dish, and which order to eat them in. There were some confusing selections, but they were delicious. The metal silver foil ball you would never otherwise put in your mouth was tasty. It was actually more fun not knowing what was coming than selecting your meal, no dish was not perfectly presented and executed with taste and texture. The sommelier did an excellent job telling us about each Spanish wine paired with our meal. The glasses were refilled when empty as well, which is unheard of in France at fixed price. The chef checked on us as did the staff. They were very involved in your experience. I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants a modern menu and gourmet experience in Madrid!

review_preview: We dined at Ramon Freixa in Madrid for my partners 40th birthday and it really was an amazing experience.  The restaurant space is intimate with very few tables, all of which however are very wide so there was no risk of fellow diners venturing into...
review_full: We dined at Ramon Freixa in Madrid for my partners 40th birthday and it really was an amazing experience. The restaurant space is intimate with very few tables, all of which however are very wide so there was no risk of fellow diners venturing into our space. As you enter you know you are somewhere really quite special.  The ambience was quiet, formal, downright posh in fact...but equally we didn't feel out of place and the staff were the perfect mix of professional yet not at all snooty. The wine list was vast, but the somelier very helpful - more helpful was that we knew the particular champagne we were looking for, but had that not been the case I have no doubt he would have helped us select the right choice from the three encylcopedias he had to browse through!  The food menu was intricate and really did have a wow factor - I had the lobster which formed two courses and really was a taste sensation (although I'd rather they hadn't kept reminding me that the broth was liquidised head!!!). The amuse bouche were wonderful too and our three course meal was more like seven by the time we had worked through all of that. In fact everything about it really was amazing - Mr Freixa himself even came out and took our orders! My feedback is that this really was an 'experience' for us and was quite formal (you need to dress up for this one). That said, for a couple looking for that special occassion (which it was), it was perfect, it made us feel very special and is something we still talk about a year later!  This all comes at a price, it wasn't cheap, but then you wouldn't expect it to be. It came to just over 300 Euro for the two of us, but 100 Euro of that was on champagne. The dining experience lasted several hours and so really although it was expensive, for what we experienced I think it is actually fair. You weuld certainly pay a lot more in London....

review_preview: My wife and I are experienced diners at Michelin starred restaurants, having eaten at many 1, 2, and 3 star establishments.  We have a good grasp of what each number of stars should entail.  The décor at RF was quite nice and the wait staff...
review_full: My wife and I are experienced diners at Michelin starred restaurants, having eaten at many 1, 2, and 3 star establishments. We have a good grasp of what each number of stars should entail. The décor at RF was quite nice and the wait staff was very friendly. Unfortunately the food was not up to par. Most of the courses had very little flavor and were lukewarm at best. Some were served cold when they were supposed to be hot. The food consistently had a mushy texture. To make matters worse, my wife's poultry had a piece of buckshot in it, and she almost broke a tooth on it! The chef clearly has many techniques under his belt, and the dishes were plated beautifully, but the food lacked the amount of flavor typically found in 1 star establishments, and the presence of metal buckshot in the food is inexcusable.

review_preview: I had lunch last Friday (January 26) by myself. I arrived at 1.30pm which, for Spain is early. I was the first guest in the restaurant and I had the privilege to enjoy the whole sunny terrace for quite a while. I took the "short...
review_full: I had lunch last Friday (January 26) by myself. I arrived at 1.30pm which, for Spain is early. I was the first guest in the restaurant and I had the privilege to enjoy the whole sunny terrace for quite a while. I took the "short lunch" (9 bites of appetizers) menu . Actually I can really tell you that after the "bites" I was full ! From the pearl oyster, to the “Crunchy coca” of foie, eal and apple every step was a pure delight. Service was amazing, attentive, very professional. The chef came to check himself if people had allergies to certain dishes. The thing I enjoyed less was the dessert. For 53 Euros, I found it was almost a bargain considering the location, the service, the quality ! The wine list is beautiful and I did enjoy they have a beautiful and different wine book for red and white wines. A great idea ! I cannot wait to experience Ramon Freixa Madrid when I come back to Madrid !

This included small gazpacho, mussels, fish with salad and desert. The portions are just right for the amount of food served. The couple who run the restaurant are both very sociable, and ready to explain the menu if needed.

What we didn't like: Nothing. Would we return? Absolutely.

review_preview: First, let me tell you that I am a picky eater and I wasn't sure if I was going to enjoy this restaurant. But I decided to be adventurous and it was well worth it. The restaurant called 2 days before our reservation to make...
review_full: First, let me tell you that I am a picky eater and I wasn't sure if I was going to enjoy this restaurant. But I decided to be adventurous and it was well worth it.  The restaurant called 2 days before our reservation to make sure we had no allergies and to ask if there was anything we really didn't like to eat. This attention to detail was the first clue as to the amazing culinary experience we were about to embark on.  We chose the 7 course meal and it was definitely enough food. I don't want to give too much detail about the menu because a) it changes daily and b) the surprise is part of what makes it so special. But everything was delicious.  In the first course, caviar was part of the dish. I'm actually not a fan of fish eggs, but I gave it a shot. But I didn't eat ALL of it, which was noticed by the waiter. He asked if anything was wrong and I told him I just wasn't a fan of caviar but that the dish was perfect. Well when another course included caviar, they were sure to leave it off my plate. The service is really spectacular - our glass was never empty, dirty plates were cleared immediately and every dish was explained thoroughly. And trust me, each one is a work of art on it's own unique plate. Every single course was served in a different way and we took pictures of every one. The waiters were patient and friendly.  I really can't say enough good things about Diverxo. You should definitely check it out for yourself. It's a little pricey - the 7 course was 75E pp before drinks, but well worth it (the total bill was about $300 US). Don't be discouraged by the slightly out of the way location.

title_review: Simply the best dining experience of my life
review_preview: Booked a res at Diverxo a month in advance for my honeymoon after hearing rave reviews and seeing it on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations. We ate a Michellin star restaurants our entire honeymoon and actually had the pleasure of eating at Tickets(Ferran Aria ie El...
review_full: Booked a res at Diverxo a month in advance for my honeymoon after hearing rave reviews and seeing it on Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations. We ate a Michellin star restaurants our entire honeymoon and actually had the pleasure of eating at Tickets(Ferran Aria ie El Bulli) in Barcelona the night before we dined at Diverxo. And I must say that although Tickets was amazing, Diverxo takes the cake and was the way to cap off our honeymoon. The experience is something that is unique and like I have never experienced before. The Chef/owner Oliver and his wife has assembled an amazing staff, and created a dining experience like no where else. They truely care and want you to leave feeling like you have just experienced the best. The atomsphere is not stuffy like you would find at some restaurants say in Paris(ie Maison Blanche), and the focus is most definitely on the FOOD rather then the appeal. The chef offers 3 set menu options, a 7 course, a 9 course, and the Diverxo experience the 12 course. I made the mistake as an indulger and ordered the 12 course(which would have been fine had I been alone or with a buddy. But my wife is 5'3 and weighs 110lbs, and the course option must be ordered for the entire table). Needless to say each course was filling, and a work of culinary art like I have never seen before. They almost needed to roll us out of the restaurant especially me considering that out of respect for the master Oliver I attempted to finish everything on my wife's plate that she was not able to finish so that we didn't send plates with food back to the kitchen. The wine/drinks were superb to go with each of the courses, and to cap it all off at the end of the night Oliver was there to greet me on our way out the door. Oliver is a star in the cooking world and I hope to have the pleasure of dining at Diverxo again in the future. If you can get a reservation and are in Madrid I would highly suggest this restaurant. It is expensive but it is worth every penny.

review_preview: We are frequent visitors to Italy, so when we choose an Italian restaurant we are looking for authenticity as well as new experiences. Oliveto in Madrid meets these requirements.The menu is limited in choice... but still offers more than many other places. The big...
review_full: We are frequent visitors to Italy, so when we choose an Italian restaurant we are looking for authenticity as well as new experiences. Oliveto in Madrid meets these requirements. The menu is limited in choice... but still offers more than many other places. The big difference is imagination: fresh Italian ideas are incorporated into the menu and even (in true Italian style) vegetarians are catered for. The wine list is sufficient for most needs: not a huge variety, but the wines are well chosen for taste and value. Tables cater for couples and perhaps one or two small groups. The restaurant is not large. Service is impeccable; swift, friendly and efficient. Our usual favourite Italian restaurant (no names please) has been getting more expensive yet more boring in recent months. Oliveto is now our restaurant of choice.

review_preview: Have never eaten at a 3 michelin star restaurant, but have eaten at 1 and 2 star restaurants in other countries..  To be honest, I was not sure what the difference would or could be.  From the minute you walk in your realise that you...
review_full: Have never eaten at a 3 michelin star restaurant, but have eaten at 1 and 2 star restaurants in other countries..  To be honest, I was not sure what the difference would or could be.  From the minute you walk in your realise that you are part of an experience, it is not just a meal. The service is efficient, waiters have great personalities and now how to interact with you. You are taken to your table which is completely enclosed/surrounded by a curtain. You are served your first drink and the various meal options are explained. Once you begin the curtains are opened and you can appreciated the decor of the restaurant - a bit like wonderland! We chose a long lunch tasting menu, 12 dishes, 9 savory and 3 sweet. This means that you are eating for 2.5 hours. I enjoyed every single dish. David Muñoz has gained his 3 stars by hard work and dedication to his profession. Having eaten in his Streetxo restaurant in Madrid, you can see that his ethos is reflected in his staff, young, lively and hardworking people. I would love to go back at dinner time, but as we had already waited 6 months for our booking, it will have to be 2017. I would say this is the best meal I have had ever. The restaurant is located in the Euro Building, not the most attractive but easy to get to. The average waitlist for lunch is 7 months and for dinner I understand over 10 months. Diverxo is the first of 2 restaurants with 3 stars in Spain. I googled the number of 3 star restaurants in the world as I was curious and Wikipedia says that there are 151.

title_review: A disappointment for the San Pellegrino List
review_preview: We have been in Diverxo last week. First we  have to say that we have been in many many other San Pellegrino Top 100 List Restaurants.Positively for us was the introduction the visit through the kitchen. Also we like the waiter who was very...
review_full: We have been in Diverxo last week.  First we have to say that we have been in many many other San Pellegrino Top 100 List Restaurants. Positively for us was the introduction the visit through the kitchen. Also we like the waiter who was very nice and exerted. The tasting menu with 18 courses lasts 5 hours for us a Long way down. Most of the courses were nice but not more. We can't remember any course at the next day.  We think the Chef does a good Job but not more. The courses are to playful but we have been there for the food. To much effort destroys often the taste of the product. In some courses we have seen his talent but not more. The Chef wants to much and for us the kitchen seams very overmotivated but we missed the taste. All in all we have been in so many better Restaurants around the world that we can easily live without diverxo. If you look for one in Madrid go to El Club Allard for us the better choice.

review_preview: Intriguing gastronomic night to say the least... For the most part the dishes were very tasty while others were too exotic, like suckling pig ears and crispy duck's tongue. Had a reservation for 1020pm (2220) and opted for the very long tasting menu. However, choosing...
review_full: Intriguing gastronomic night to say the least... For the most part the dishes were very tasty while others were too exotic, like suckling pig ears and crispy duck's tongue. Had a reservation for 1020pm (2220) and opted for the very long tasting menu. However, choosing this menu may take your dinner experience around three hours long. I did not have a problem with the duration of my dinner, especially for the price I was paying, but the staff towards the end seemed eager for me to finish my plates quickly, as some of them would be coming around my table several times and asking me if I was done. It appeared to me that they really wanted to go home and be done, since I was the last table standing in the restaurant. This part annoyed me a bit since I do not like to be rushed. Perhaps they should not offer reservations at 10pm...But overall experience was good. I am posting the menu I was served so one can have an idea of what to expect.

review_preview: It's the second time I review Diverxo. I paid a second visit in this notable restaurant. Indeed the dishes were evolved and nothing was the same (after almost 6 months since my first visit). I noticed that even the lienzo with the Ossobucco, which I...
review_full: It's the second time I review Diverxo. I paid a second visit in this notable restaurant. Indeed the dishes were evolved and nothing was the same (after almost 6 months since my first visit). I noticed that even the lienzo with the Ossobucco, which I found a bit weird on my last visit, has changed and, instead of macarrones, the chef combined the ossobucco with ravioli al azafran which was much much better! So the dishes evolve and get better. The only dish which I found again a bit weird was the Cocotxa fishy creations, which were too fishy for me (always for my taste). There is nothing more to say on the food as you really need to experience it in order to understand and there are not enough words to say about it / it's surely incredible. The reason I'm rating Diverxo again (with 4 points instead of 5) is that I noticed some worsening of the service in general. In a restaurant of this kind and of this level you cannot disregard the importance of serving your customers. I had to look around for about 5-10 minutes to get an eye contact with someone who could poor some water on my glass. I mean...no problem I could do it by myself if the water bottle was on the table...but the personnel needs to continuously look the customers in the eye, look on their table and track their need; they don't need to look down and only do their specific tasks. I had the impression that they were acting like robots, because obviously they have many things to do, BUT they should not forget that the customer is sitting there and he/she might have a need. They go only by-the-script, which is a shame for such restaurant. So please pay some attention to the customer and the service. It's a pity that such excellence in dish preparation, is overshadowed by service which is not perfect as it should be. All the best until the third time.

review_preview: Not only my favorite meal of the trip, but probably a top 10 meal of all time for me.Against my wife's request I opted for the Diverxo 1 tasting menu rather than the tasting menu that was a little smaller. Diverxo 1 was the...
review_full: Not only my favorite meal of the trip, but probably a top 10 meal of all time for me. Against my wife's request I opted for the Diverxo 1 tasting menu rather than the tasting menu that was a little smaller. Diverxo 1 was the 3rd largest of the 4 tasting menus offered. I didn't know what to expect since the restaurant combines chinese and spanish cuisine. There were a few items that were too extreme for my wife so I had to eat them (ie hot and sour soup w special noodles - baby eels, fried duck tongues, and squid heads with strawberries). The best bites were some type of oxtail pastry type thing topped with baby eels which was the first course, won ton/dumpling with a cracker, and ox which came as a thick narrow strip steak. I could also eat those fried duck tongues by the bag. So good. Monkfish was also very rich and good. Our reservation was at 10 and we weren't out of there until after 1. If I had to do it over again I would get the 2nd option tasting menu. The 3rd was just way too much food. I can't imagine the Chef David tasting menu which is the 4th option. Service was great and it was real nice talking to the wife of the chef (owner). Just a very good, very rich meal and one that I won't be forgetting anytime soon.

title_review: Off the beaten path and worth seeking out!
review_preview: My husband (who was born in Mislata) and have travelled around the world, so we have a lot of dining experiences to which we can compare every new one. During our last trip to Valencia/Mislata, we visited Sabe a Gloria probably six or eight times...
review_full: My husband (who was born in Mislata) and have travelled around the world, so we have a lot of dining experiences to which we can compare every new one. During our last trip to Valencia/Mislata, we visited Sabe a Gloria probably six or eight times over the month and had unforgettable experiences every single time. The quality of the food and the kind attention from Gloria and Julián make for a great experience. Imagine Spanish home cooking, as delicious as what a grandmother would make. Now elevate it a bit. Add a bit of sophistication, some touches of elegance. That's the top-notch food from Sabe a Gloria.  We brought a group of students to live in Mislata for that month, and we brought them all here (some went more than once). This diverse crowd included vegetarians and avowed carnivores, and everyone told me they loved it! Fish (especially bacalao, or cod) dishes that even convinced the people who thought they hated fish, meats (pork, beef, poultry) that were expertly prepared, legume-based dishes with impressive flavor, salads of the highest quality.  The most memorable dish (for me, at least) was the crema pasiega, a dessert that is a little like a crême brulée but is baked for several hours at a very low temperature, causing the cream to rise to the top and make a buttery crust... it's a good thing I live so far away, else I'd have to go eat this several times a week. The drinks pairings suggested by Julián, who is an expert sommelier, were always 100% spot on, from the dry aperitifs to the wines with the meal to the dessert wines.  Amazingly, even as busy as they are, Gloria and Julián took the time to learn about us, about our preferences, and sat down with us to create a going-away dinner for our students that left them all open-mouthed. Their reception and attention, combined with the best Spanish homecoming you can eat anywhere, made an indelible impression on us. We have taken so many people to Sabe a Gloria, and everyone leaves with the same reaction, whether they are Mediterranean Spaniards who know how this food is supposed to taste, or university students from the U.S. who have never been to the region before, or even elementary kids.  I can't wait for my next trip to Mislata (in June), mainly so that I can return to this restaurant. Only the highest praise for this top-notch establishment!

title_review: Great homemade food next to my place!
review_preview: I moved to Mislata nearly two months ago, and this is the only restaurant I have tried in town, as it is so good and well-organized I do not want to be disappointed elsewhere. To date I come here twice a week, when I feel...
review_full: I moved to Mislata nearly two months ago, and this is the only restaurant I have tried in town, as it is so good and well-organized I do not want to be disappointed elsewhere. To date I come here twice a week, when I feel like being treated with a lunch menu, a feast usually comprised of three different starters, one main dish to choose, and a delicious dessert. Super fulfiling. I have to mention that I have never ordered a-la-carte, as Gloria always comes with recommendations that sound mouthwatering enough for me to say yes. The setting of the restaurant is also very inspiring and well-decorated. My dad, who came to visit, joined me for lunch to try one "cocido madrileño" and he was very satisfied - and he is from Madrid, so he knows a thing or two about cocidos! I cannot compare this place to other restaurants nearby, as I am still relatively new in town and I have only tried some on the city centre of Valencia and this one in Mislata, but I can highly recommend this place to anyone who is in the area.

title_review: eclectic decor and presentation, but very impressive food
review_preview: This Michelin 3-star prides itself on being non-traditional in every respect. The decor is eclectic, with a flying pigs motif. Waitstaff are dress in white shirts and black pants, but with mis-sonneted suspenders and often with spiky hair. We enjoyed the largest tasting menu, which...
review_full: This Michelin 3-star prides itself on being non-traditional in every respect. The decor is eclectic, with a flying pigs motif. Waitstaff are dress in white shirts and black pants, but with mis-sonneted suspenders and often with spiky hair. We enjoyed the largest tasting menu, which was about 16 courses, but many of the courses consisted of 2-3 sub-courses, so dinner took about 4 hours. There were several courses where one is encouraged to use fingers vs. utensils; I would have preferred to use a spoon. The wine list if good, but not as good as most 3 star restaurants in Spain, and the somm was not very impressive: the I asked about the vintage of a cava on the list he insisted that the wine had been aged (in bottle, on the lees) for 15 years, rather than simply answering my question. In fact the wine (which we consumed at another restaurant the previous night) was a 2007 vintage, which was aged for 5 years on the lees. The ambience is quite noisy, not my preference, but there's no doubt that the food is very impressive.

review_preview: After a once-in-a-lifetime trip to Spain for 4 professionals from Chicago which began with amazing dining experiences at Martin Berasategui and Arzak...on this evening, we were declined our reservation at Diver XO despite that it was confirmed by email 6 months prior. The restaurant's front...
review_full: After a once-in-a-lifetime trip to Spain for 4 professionals from Chicago which began with amazing dining experiences at Martin Berasategui and Arzak...on this evening, we were declined our reservation at Diver XO despite that it was confirmed by email 6 months prior. The restaurant's front staff asked to see our confirmation; after we presented it, they spent 45 minutes trying to explain how the mishap occurred, with no attempt to provide a legitimate solution. Finally, The David Munoz came to investigate, and we naturally assumed he would come up with a solution to make this difficult situation palatable. Instead of offering a sincere apology, he was shockingly dismissive, providing the explanation that his restaurant -- which holds multiple seatings at various times -- simply could not make any type of accommodation to allow international travelers like us to even taste the food that has earned such international acclaim. Furthermore, he asked us to leave without any alternative solution - namely no recommendation to salvage our evening in Madrid at any other restaurant. It is notable that he owns and runs a more casual restaurant down the street, but this was not mentioned as an alternative.  This experience is telltale in several ways. After dining as guests of Elena Arzak the night before, we quickly realized the implications of a self-proclaimed "avant-garde" chef, who believes that he stands above all other 3-Michelin-star geniuses in the value he provides. As guests of a large number of three-star Michelin restaurants across the world, we found it honestly incomprehensible and doubted that any of David Munoz's counterparts would ever have behaved in the same way if presented with the same situation. It speaks to the arrogance and blatant disregard for customers and his disrespect of the most important aspect of running a Michelin-star restaurant - customer service. In conclusion, we would encourage serious caution when considering Diver XO as part of your Spanish haute cuisine experience.

We were even luckier to get a call from DiverXo that there have been a cancellation for the day we selected.  First of all, the decoration of the restaurant is spectacular and very original. The curtains that surrounded our table gave us some privacy at the beginning of the diner (they then opened them in order to appreciate the unique decoration of the restaurant). The service was extremely pleasant, the waiters were very efficient, nice, helpful and with a touch of a humor that we particularly appreciated. Regarding the food, every dish we had was beyond original. Except one dish (the ravioli), everything was absolutely spectacular. The chef chose the order of each dish and the quantity are simply perfect in order to enjoy the almost 20 dishes we had to try.  Overall, I would say that the experience is so engaging that you don't even realize that you have spent three hours enjoying the menu.  I would strongly recommend this experience, it was unforgettable for us!

review_preview: The entire experience can be described as a show, starting with the entry and the decoration: flying pink pigs and butterflies, colorful ice cream cones to keep the wine and water bottles. First a tour through the restaurant and the kitchen, and then the mail...
review_full: The entire experience can be described as a show, starting with the entry and the decoration: flying pink pigs and butterflies, colorful ice cream cones to keep the wine and water bottles. First a tour through the restaurant and the kitchen, and then the mail can start. The meal starts surrounded by heavy dark curtains having only candles to light everything up, as the meal continues the curtains are lifted and the lights are turned on.  All this and many other details to create the show feeling.  All over the meal, there was a constant flow of waiters, all very friendly and helpful. And all wearing sneakers :). The meal consists of several sequences and each of 2-3 plates of food. All in all, they try to bring different tastes from different part of the world together, some more successful then others. The curry was rather average, as was the ravioli and the curros. Delicious were the langoustines with strawberry gazpacho, the pulpo with the bone marrow and coconut bubbles. One intended element of surprise are the fish bones, real ones, double fried thus becoming crunchy snack. The dessert was better than average but not exceptional.  The entire experience was part show part culinary, making one wonder if it wasn't too much show and if there shouldn't actually be more focus on the actual food.

title_review: Disappointing for a Michelin starred restaurant... not worth it
review_preview: We waited 6 months for our reservation to DiverXO, so we were very excited for our dinner.  We chose the middle option of the menu, so we received a wide variety of courses.  Needless to say, most of it was disappointing.The experience was probably...
review_full: We waited 6 months for our reservation to DiverXO, so we were very excited for our dinner. We chose the middle option of the menu, so we received a wide variety of courses. Needless to say, most of it was disappointing. The experience was probably the best part. We started out surrounded by a curtain with some props and it tried to approximate a surreal breakfast experience. It was interesting and set a good stage, but the rest of the meal was not as creative or memorable. The props around the restaurant were creative, but seemed random and odd rather than cohesive or edgy. The food was spotty. Some of the dishes were really excellent with many different subtle flavors coming together to create a feeling of "wow!", while other dishes were average. Not at all what I would expect from a 3 Michelin star restaurant. Finally, as others have said, the service was lacking. It started out well, but the servers were slow and inattentive.  Overall, not worth the wait, time or money... There are many other worthy restaurants in Madrid that I would recommend over this overrated one.

I am not an expert to review precisely the food (canvases). I tried 8 of the canvases and I liked equally all of them. A couple of them were surprisingly spicy (that's quite...risky for such restaurant but I really liked it). Execution and timing was perfect. The only dish that tasted weird was the Lienzo 10 where the chef fuses Italian and indian tastes (how easy can that be?). Probably the macarrones filled with a mixture of buffalo yogurt and tandoori was a bit too much for my taste. Apart from the food the whole scenery is very well directed and it is dynamically changing like a rolling circus :)

title_review: My favorite treat, this time with a trick.
review_preview: This time around travel kept me away from home on my birthday, so my wife decided to treat me to a family dinner (a party of six) at Ramón Freixa's, a place I love just as much as I do his parents place in Barcelona....
review_full: This time around travel kept me away from home on my birthday, so my wife decided to treat me to a family dinner (a party of six) at Ramón Freixa's, a place I love just as much as I do his parents place in Barcelona. We went for an easy choice: an experience tasting menu incl wines. In a nutshell, a creative yet well crafted cuisine, lovely and welcoming ambience, friendliness and perfectly tuned in staff, interesting wines... We will certainly remember this evening, although not just as one might think.  Seems The oysters were not in their best shape and played hard on us, with two of us even having to check into hospital for treatment and temporary observation. The others made it somehow through the day... Still Freixa remains one of my favorites in Madrid but I reckon we will keep our hands off oysters for quite a while.

review_preview: My husband and I came to Madrid for a 5-day holiday and reserved a table at Ramon Freixa....we had expectations that this dinner would be a highlight of our trip.  I wish this was a 5-Star review, but sadly it is not.  What started as...
review_full: My husband and I came to Madrid for a 5-day holiday and reserved a table at Ramon Freixa....we had expectations that this dinner would be a highlight of our trip. I wish this was a 5-Star review, but sadly it is not. What started as a superior-in-every-way dining experience deteriorated at the midway point. We selected "The Experience" menu with the wine pairings.  We quickly embarked on some of the most exquisite courses we had ever had, with each course, we marveled that this dinner could become one of the all-time best. The seafood courses were complex creations of the most flavorful ingredients and combinations.  But between two superior seafood courses and the upcoming meat course, we had a delay - a very long delay. No explanation, nothing. Just some nods and smiles. Our wine glasses waited empty for the next pairing. We absolutely lost our mood - we became irked. When the meat course finally arrived, we found it absolutely a failure. I beautifully prepared pancetta, with dense fat and barely any meat, and with almost tasteless sides of vegetables purees. Although the dishes remained barely touched, there was no question by the serving staff. When the dishes were removed, I made the comment that the course had been delayed and was a failure. Again, smiles and nods. As you may guess, by this time, we were not pleased with Ramon Freixa. We simply picked at the cheese course and the dessert courses. The delay had cost us time and we were now at 3+ hours for dinner. We asked for the check, paid and left. Note - there was no sign of the chef in the dining room during our visit. Overall, my husband would give this restaurant only 2 stars; I gave three due to the wonderful first part of our meal. Very Disappointed.

review_preview: We ate at the Ramon Freixa in Madrid a couple of weeks ago.  This is the first 2 Michelin starred restaurant that we have eaten.  The restaurant was impressive. The service was excellent, from the moment you get off the taxi up to when you...
review_full: We ate at the Ramon Freixa in Madrid a couple of weeks ago. This is the first 2 Michelin starred restaurant that we have eaten. The restaurant was impressive. The service was excellent, from the moment you get off the taxi up to when you leave the premises. The food was fantastic. The ingredients are from different parts of Spain. So you are going on a journey. The Spanish cava sparkling wine that came with it was so good. The main entree that i got, 3 meat canelloni, was very good. The meal was just enough to make me full. Most of all, the chef was very nice, talking to the customers and also obliged to have a picture taken. The service was very, very impressive. Overall, i will fly to Madrid again just to have another lunch, or better yet, dinner!

review_preview: This was our first experience of a tasting menu so were a little apprehensive about what to expect. We were greeted by Ramon at the door and quickly shown to our table. Ramon came to us to ask what we had chosen to eat and...
review_full: This was our first experience of a tasting menu so were a little apprehensive about what to expect. We were greeted by Ramon at the door and quickly shown to our table. Ramon came to us to ask what we had chosen to eat and if we had any allergies. We had booked and planned for the 20 course tasting menu with wine pairing. A good choice as each course is so different that just to chose one or two wines would have been too difficult. I was a bit wary of taking photos of our food but the guests on the next table seemed to know the chef were happy snapping away so I didn't feel uncomfortable about joining in. Down to the food. Each course was a joy. There were some surprises, first time for frogs legs, scorpion fish and rock fish (all delicious). Not too sure about the sea cucumber though but it did offer another texture dimension to the dish. My personal favourite elements were the risotto (wheat?) part of the surf and turf and the consommé which came as part of one of the fish dishes. My husband's favourite was the fish.  The wine pairing was exquisite, the sommelier was knowledgeable without being condescending and each wine perfectly matched the dishes.  Throughout the meal the staff (all elegantly dressed in matching uniforms) displayed an exceptional level of friendly and efficient service that ran like a Swiss watch. My only criticism would be that Ramon Freixa himself spent an inordinate amount of time with the guests on the next table, maybe they were his friends or VIPs but it did feel that he was more interested in their reactions to the food than the other diners.  In my opinion he should give each table equal attention.  All in all a fabulous dining experience though.

review_preview: My wife and I ate dinner here and had the standard menu.  I was thinking about ordering the longer menu but our server stressed that we shouldn't order the long menu -too much food, takes too long, etc.  I found that pretty odd.  Why offer...
review_full: My wife and I ate dinner here and had the standard menu. I was thinking about ordering the longer menu but our server stressed that we shouldn't order the long menu -too much  food, takes too long, etc. I found that pretty odd. Why offer the long menu if you're going to talk everyone out of it? I didn't see any other diners eating the long menu so I think they must  have been successful in talking everyone out of it. We were told that the standard menu consisted of 7 courses/canvases. We ended up getting 11 though - you get a complimentary appetizer and 3 dessert courses in addition to the 7 on the menu.  The food was outstanding. Everything was very creative with lots of little surprises throughout the evening. It took about 3 hours from start to finish. Service was good but not perfect. E.g. it took them 10-15 minutes to bring a wine list after I requested it. They also forgot to bring us a green drink that accompanied one of the courses.  Overall, we had a great experience. Also, it was a relative bargain for food of this quality. Not sure if it deserves its three star Michelin rating given the service shortcomings. There's no issue IMO, however, that it merits a 5 star rating on TA.

Can't wait to come back. Cons: some of the waiters don't speak English. And couple of times they couldn't answer some of our questions ("these are the cheeks of an animal" "ok, which animal" "i don't know"). This I wouldn't really tolerate at any other place, but the food here mesmerized me, so I didn't really care. Whatever animal, it tasted like heaven.  MORE OF THAT! :)

So until they find the translator each and every time, we decided to say goodbye to the courses that were supposed to be served hot.The architecture of the restaurant was too blusterous. Even the music drove me crazy, I believe we heard a song called Alegria about 6-8 times in two hours.  In fact the word pretentious describes my whole experience there.  In my opinion they should be more careful about the food they serve and not about the clothes they wear, or their black polished naιls. I would never dine there again even if it was on the house.

title_review: An absolutely unique and exceptional dining experience.
review_preview: Ramon Freixa had been on my mind for a couple of years, but due to tight scheduling while travelling and the restaurant's popularity, I hadn't had the chance to dine here until this May.I couldn't find availability, yet again, on this trip, but my...
review_full: Ramon Freixa had been on my mind for a couple of years, but due to tight scheduling while travelling and the restaurant's popularity, I hadn't had the chance to dine here until this May. I couldn't find availability, yet again, on this trip, but my assistant emailed the restaurant asking for any vacancies for a small group of 5 people, and Mrs. Maria Sanchez, the reservations agent at the restaurant, was extremely kind offering us their private dining room, which we happily accepted. The restaurant's entrance is a bit oddly located; it's part of the new SPG Unico Hotel, in the classy neighbourhood of Barrio de Salamanca, but the access is down a ramp that looks like it'll take you to a garage, rather than through the hotel's door. My partner, a friend, and myself arrived a bit early and were shown to the private dining room straight away and served champagne while we waited for the other couple. The common area of the restaurant is pretty small; just a handful of tables, so that explains why it's so difficult to find an open time slot. The private dining room was rather large, which allowed for plenty of table space; they had situated our plates in the centre of a 12-person table, so we all sat very comfortably. There's a sliding smoked-glass door that gives the room from the kitchen area, and huge opening covered with a thick curtain separating it from the common dining room. We had already set our minds on the 25-course menu (which turned out to have more than 25 courses in the end). I'm a fan of long dinners with lots of courses, and I love trying as much of a chef's work as humanly possible during one sitting, so this worked very well for me. Service was exquisite. They were extremely attentive with our group, always caring for our drinks, refilling our water, making sure everything was perfect. We all spoke both English and Spanish except for my partner, so our waiters and servers all addressed us in English (most of them with excellent communications skills, I must say). They made our meal even more enjoyable with their personal touch. Before I dig into the food, I have to take my hat off to Mr. Freixa himself, who graced us with his presence several times during the meal, gentle-mannered, regaling us with little anecdotes, or just presenting a dish himself. I've been to quite a few Michelin restaurants by now and I have never felt so taken care of... I'd dare say I even felt special (and my co-diners all agreed with me). Now, 25 (probably 28ish, though I admit I forgot to take pictures of some of them) courses are a lot of courses, so regardless of how fast the service is, it'll take a minimum of 4 hours eat your way through this menu. 4 absolutely wonderful hours filled with culinary magic. Delicate flavour combinations, exquisite ingredients of the best quality, imaginative modern dishes with Spanish inspirations. Dish after dish after dish of food that made our eyes water. Sighs pleasure, gasps of excitement were constantly heard coming from our table. Nothing I say, no amount of adjectives I use, will do justice to such phenomenal dining experience. You have to try it to fully understand my review.

title_review: Highlight of our trip...Delicious food sans pretense
review_preview: We enjoyed the Short menu available Monday - Friday lunch only. 53 euro pp.First to arrive glass of house Cava & Negroni. Both drinks deliciousNext shaved paper thin pieces of salami on thin crackers with tomato spread. Finest interpretation of deliNext shitake...
review_full: We enjoyed the Short menu available Monday - Friday lunch only. 53 euro pp. First to arrive glass of house Cava & Negroni. Both drinks delicious Next shaved paper thin pieces of salami on thin crackers with tomato spread. Finest interpretation of deli Next shitake freeze dried? shitake mushroom...it's the original mushroom with earthy taste but such interesting twist of texture crunchy and airy. Weird but good Fork of thai coconut on a piece of seaweed with pine nut...this is floating on dry ice. Artistic presentation Next fois on paper thin crackers with eel & apple and stone on spoon. Tasted delicious but I don't know what the rock was made of, it kinda popped in my mouth and it was delicious liquid broth of some kind tasted of pine nuts. Next up is an egg with a mousse like texture (similar to Japanese steamed egg but finer texture) taste of trout broth and flavored with paprika Next quail egg with caviar on waffle House made bread offered (these are flown in 1/2 baked from Barcelona) and we have a green olive oil (fresh taste), butter and herbs. I can't get enough of the bread but have to remember not to stuff myself because next is the main...choice of or tasting of both... Canelonni with 3 types of meat, mushroom sauce...so darn delicious. If I really had to pick one main I would go for this one. The other main is a risotto with shredded duck confit & prawn broth & shrimp ceviche on a piece of lime Finally we get to the dessert, we have chocolate mousse, caramel sauce and sponge. It's artistic but nothing that I would remember for a long time kind of dessert (or I'm just too jet lagged and intoxicated by this time)...2 hours into our meal Included are a little plate of sweets, 2 chocolate truffles and little baked goodies. Meal also includes coffee, water, bread service and 10% VAT. $60 per person for all this in a beautiful setting, elegant stemware & plating but without the stuffy atmosphere of a traditional fine dining restaurant.

review_preview: Where do you start with this? Minor criticism I think, as it is only minor. The restaurant needed gentle background music to start. These places can be quite clinical and uppity if you leave the guest with no noise at all. It is supposed to...
review_full: Where do you start with this? Minor criticism I think, as it is only minor. The restaurant needed gentle background music to start. These places can be quite clinical and uppity if you leave the guest with no noise at all. It is supposed to be a feast for the senses, and yes I appreciate you want the guest to hear various bubblings and sizzlings as amazing dishes are served, but surely this can be managed if balanced right? The only criticism of the food? The scorpion fish needed a miniscule amount of salt to taste, & regarding the drink, this was the first time I have had Sherry served with a dish, albeit an incredible 30 year old Sherry! but it was still quite harsh I thought with food - but that is a personal opinion. Now...Enough!...This place is amazing. How many 2 star eateries do you know, whereby the titled Chef humbly comes out at the beginning of the night, introduces themselves to you personally, and then asks you what would you like for Dinner? How this restaurant has got 2 michelin stars and not 3 is beyond me? The dishes are more 2/3 star consistent than at El Club Allard, and having eaten now at Six 2* restaurants, the only Chef to match this standard of cooking is Marcus Waring (who also deserves 3 stars in my opinion!). The technique, flavours, textures, balance, and the pure freshness and quality of ingredients were mind blowing. The (majority Spanish) wine flight served was incredible, and was an education in what world class Spanish wines are actually out there. It was an incredible Dinner, made even more special by the staff kindly acknowledging our wedding anniversary. Utterly brilliant and highly recommended.

title_review: Maybe Best Meal We had in Spain!
review_preview: We went to La Mi Venta based on the high TA rating, but almost passed due to it being the last day of a two-week trip and we were tired!  But, since we had made the reservation, we decided to go and we were thankful...
review_full: We went to La Mi Venta based on the high TA rating, but almost passed due to it being the last day of a two-week trip and we were tired! But, since we had made the reservation, we decided to go and we were thankful that we did! The restaurant is easy to find and is in a quaint area near the palace. We arrived before the restaurant opened for dinner, but the bar was open and we had a glass of wine while waiting. This is a traditional Spanish restaurant with a large menu! It is a very very small restaurant with two small rooms in the cellar area (5 tables in one room and 4 in other) and a small room upstairs with 4 tables. So reservations in advance are a must. We ate in the cellar in the "cave" that was used to cure the hams! Very romantic and intimate setting. The service was impeccable throughout the meal. Carlos waited on us and he speaks excellent English which greatly helped in selecting courses and wine. He is also an outstanding server--friendly, outgoing and enthusiastic! We split a salad, and for entrees ordered a steak and a pork steak. Both were perfectly prepared and amazing cuts of meat. The pork was especially delicious--it was the Iberian pork which has a different texture and taste--a must try!! We also enjoyed a great bottle of Spanish red which perfectly complemented the entrees. We finished with a wonderful dessert. This was probably the best dinner we had while in Spain based on the ambiance, quality of food and service. I highly recommend for a very special dining experience!

title_review: Another Thursday night with the boys
review_preview: First time at the new premises and a big change from both the first and second Restaurant.   Decor much more imaginative and sophisticated - albeit in a fun way - than the previous locations. A feel good factor descends as you arrive and leave coats...
review_full: First time at the new premises and a big change from both the first and second Restaurant. Decor much more imaginative and sophisticated - albeit in a fun way - than the previous locations.  A feel good factor descends as you arrive and leave coats before climbing the stairs to the restaurant.  Tables nicely spaced and large with plenty of room  Two menus on offer, a normal and the glutton! We went for the glutton - of course.  A mixture of textures and flavours. Presentation good and many dishes came with multiple parts - finish one part and the next arrived.  Most dishes had some spice to them - which generally worked.  Compared to previous visit a couple of years ago the food showed more maturity and less trying for he sake of trying.  Good selection of wines - much improved on the previous restaurants, although not sure that it is sufficient for a 3 star restaurant.  Service good and professional. Many young and willing in their multicoloured munchkin outfits. Not at all stuffy as in certain other places.  Good fun and definitely worth a return visit - just a shame about the 6 month plus waiting list.

review_preview: I really cannot express how wonderful our experience was at Diverxo. We are two foodies from the Napa Valley that have eaten in 3-Michelin star restaurants all over the world, and nothing has compared to Diverxo. The food is so incredibly inventive (think fried duck...
review_full: I really cannot express how wonderful our experience was at Diverxo. We are two foodies from the Napa Valley that have eaten in 3-Michelin star restaurants all over the world, and nothing has compared to Diverxo. The food is so incredibly inventive (think fried duck tounges, tomato crusted herring with beef, and cornichons with white chocolate) that every course brought with it a new suprise in both flavors and textures. Besides the food and the ambiance the chef and his wife are just the nicest people who clearly have a passion for what they do. We went with the Diverxo Menu which I believe was 9 courses, and about halfway through we decided up the anty and go with the Festival Menu and add 5 courses because we didn't want the meal to end! Overall it was an unforgettable experience, and we will be returning every time we are in Madrid!

review_preview: We are two foodies from Chicago who have dined at many of the great restaurants in America and Europe.  Up to now we have never been able to decide which was our greatest meal, because there have been so many.  But midway through our 12-course...
review_full: We are two foodies from Chicago who have dined at many of the great restaurants in America and Europe. Up to now we have never been able to decide which was our greatest meal, because there have been so many. But midway through our 12-course tasting menu at Diverxo, we both said, at the same exact moment, "This is it! This is the best meal we've ever had!" Chef Munoz is a wunderkind who not only makes the most beautiful presentation of food we've ever seen (with white plates designed for optimal photographs), but each bite is an explosion of intense flavor. I can honestly say I never really knew what rhubarb tasted like before, as it's always been blended with strawberries or apples, but at Diverxo, one of our desserts was a celebration of all things rhubarb that changed our world. If you go to Madrid, don't miss this superb restaurant. It's not close to the tourist area but is worth the trip. We have been home for two weeks and wish we were there right now.

review_preview: We are 3 family members on vacation and ate at DIVERXO last night. Couldn't have been better. Reservations obtained by the website and email - handled perfectly. Food was "wow". No menu so every dish that arrived was a surprise. Visually amazing, and many dishes...

No menu so every dish that arrived was a surprise. Visually amazing, and many dishes came with a surprise taste or texture element. The night began with our waiter telling us his English was minimal (that worried me a bit) but we were served by several staff - all had passable to good English. At my request, they made wine recommendations from their extensive list - Ossian 2009 (white) and Pielago 2010 (red). Excellent and very affordable by US standards. We love food and expensive (very) restaurants, and DIVERXO is one of the best I've ever eaten at.

review_preview: Ramon Freixa was the final dinner of my three night indulgence (A'barra, Cebo and Ramon Freixa, see all reviews) in Madrid. Each dinner was exceptional in its own way, elegant, beautifully presented and delicious, creative food. Each small bite or dish was exquisite, each meal...
review_full: Ramon Freixa was the final dinner of my three night indulgence (A'barra, Cebo and Ramon Freixa, see all reviews) in Madrid. Each dinner was exceptional in its own way, elegant, beautifully presented and delicious, creative food. Each small bite or dish was exquisite, each meal was substantial and I loved the creativity of each of these chefs. The service at each location was superb, the staff were extremely educated on the dishes and eager to share their knowledge, and extremely attentive to your needs and desires. You left each location feeling pampered. Each location was a special, elegant restaurant where you did not feel out of place in jeans and a nice shirt. Each was artfully decorated, and beautiful in its own right. Note: These dinners allow the chefs to be creative in their art, this is not the place you come to for standard fare. Enjoying this meal includes opening you mind and palate to the possibilities and creativity of each of these artists.  Dinner at each of these restaurants is a decadent treat and I was privileged to be able to do three of these on consecutive nights. Specific to Ramon Freixa. This was my favorite dinner among the three.  Food: Exquisite, creative food. We did the Experience Menu in 20 bites. I loved the creative combinations of flavors, the different textures and the flow through the courses. The dinner was substantial and we left feeling full. They have a wonderful wine list, full of gems if you look hard enough.  Ambiance: We ate at the newly renovated restaurant on day 4 after they opened. We loved the decor and the luxurious touches, the decor did not however distract from the food that was the star. The space makes you feel comfortable and relaxed.  Service: Exceptional. The staff was attentive and always on hand to help in any way. We never had to ask for anything, it was like they anticipated our every need.  We loved the restaurant and would recommend it highly.
