review_preview: Ramon Freixa Madrid is one unforgettable culinary and molecular gastronomy experience! The short menu gives a glimpse of Chef Ramon Freixa's playfulness and creativity without sacrificing the natural flavours of every ingredient. Chef Ramon Freixa magically surprises your palate with wonderful ephemeral flavours that leave...
review_full: Ramon Freixa Madrid is one unforgettable culinary and molecular gastronomy experience! The short menu gives a glimpse of Chef Ramon Freixa's playfulness and creativity without sacrificing the natural flavours of every ingredient. Chef Ramon Freixa magically surprises your palate with wonderful ephemeral flavours that leave a smile on your lips. Among his main courses, the wild salmon with bitter herbs, pork belly soup with Iberican squid niguiri and the three roasted meats cannelloni are equally divine! The "postre" or dessert is a fantastic symphony of a thin sheets of rolled chocolate wafer accompanied by milk chocolate mousse, dark chocolate, cream and a crispy hazelnut sponge cake that looked like a sea sponge. To the very last, when you cap your splendid meal with coffee, you will be spoiled yet again with a delectable petit fours. What tops this experience is that despite the fame, Chef Ramon Freixa remains genuinely warm and very welcoming, taking time to check on his guests. This makes you feel at home in this magical dining place. And what Chef Ramon Freixa said about preparing food to make people happy, this is exactly what he does, dish after dish. Thank you for this wonderful gift that is Ramon Freixa Madrid - truly deserving of its Michelin stars!

review_preview: This restaurant was recommended to us by friends that had travelled to Madrid last year. They liked it so much they ate here twice. We were instructed to dine in the cave (you can state your preference in the notes section when you book online)...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended to us by friends that had travelled to Madrid last year. They liked it so much they ate here twice. We were instructed to dine in the cave (you can state your preference in the notes section when you book online) and we would recommend the same. The main dining room is fine but it doesn’t have the same character. The restaurant is located on a side street very close to the Royal Palace but for some reason our taxi driver had difficulty finding it. He turned off his meter, recognizing that it was taking him longer that it should have which was contrary to everything you hear about taxis and tourists in Europe! We tried several items on the menu, perhaps too many, and ordered a bottle of wine. The service was great as was the food and all at a reasonable price. We would definitely recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: This restaurant is pure quality. Small, personal, very high quality food, outstanding staff and very good value for moneyWe were lucky to get in as we only gave an hours notice and the restaurant was fully booked up (we soon found out why)The...
review_full: This restaurant is pure quality. Small, personal, very high quality food, outstanding staff and very good value for money We were lucky to get in as we only gave an hours notice and the restaurant was fully booked up (we soon found out why) The Manager who was very friendly showed us to our table which was in the old “curing room” - full of character and exceptionally clean with an arched brick ceiling, with the 200 hooks that used to hang the Jamon . Our waiter Carlos was very knowledgeable about the menu and told us that all the Jamon and Pork came from the owners farm The food was exceptional and the wine list very good. Everything was beautifully presented and cooked to perfection. We shared a starter, had wine and a mains each and the bill was 55 Euro. Free liqueurs on the house and with a final lovely touch one of the bar waiters came out of the restaurant to help hail a taxi What a lovely place and lovely evening - I can’t wait to book again to pre-order the roast goatling - sounds delicious

title_review: A waste of money given that there was not the variety I expected
review_preview: I want to rate this restaurant as GOOD, not Average and not Very Good.Diverxo is fusion spanish/chinese.  It offers 3 expensive tasting menus (6 - 9 or 12 courses).  You do not get to see what each course will present.  We opted for the...
review_full: I want to rate this restaurant as GOOD, not Average and not Very Good. Diverxo is fusion spanish/chinese. It offers 3 expensive tasting menus (6 - 9 or 12 courses). You do not get to see what each course will present. We opted for the 12, thinking there would be a little bit of everything, however, the 12 course ended up being too much and things started to repeat themselves. I did not expect the overkill of fish and seafood in the dishes. I unfortunately can only tolerate so much of it before it becomes overwhelming for my palate and nose. My husband who will eat every and anything agreed that the fishiness in the food started to take a toll on him after awhile. At first it was admirable that our wait staff noticed that I was not able to eat a few things. I was told that my menu was going to be tweaked so that it would not have as much of the fish and seafood. But, as the dishes kept coming, the fishiness was still potent. After I had to ask what was going on, I was then told that the chef said I was just going to have to go with it. The wait staff was very professional and the course presentations are all beautiful and dramatic. The plating is fun and different with the various shapes and colors. While there were whimsical pink piggies with wings on each table, I'm not sure I appreciated their meaning.

title_review: Misses target by trying too hard
review_preview: Let me set this straight first, although I will bring up negative points, I have to say and remind anyone intending to attend that this restaurant is a unique experience which is worth going, at least once, going back again is up to you. It...
review_full: Let me set this straight first, although I will bring up negative points, I have to say and remind anyone intending to attend that this restaurant is a unique experience which is worth going, at least once, going back again is up to you. It not not overpriced considering the type of standing (3 star Michelin) we are talking about, and indeed wines are considerably cheap, which comes as a surprise. Th experience begins as early as when you first walk into the reception area, being welcome by someone wearing a futuristic type of uniform with trainers on.  The decoration throughout the restaurant is made to surprise up to very little details you will or may (or not) notice and come across. The setting is also set to revolutionise this rather conservative and predictable industry, kitchen block standing in the middle of the restaurant room, tables places so they can be isolated using light curtains, therefore creating differents types of ambiance. The staff and service in general is also quite amazingly different and gives this experience a much appreciated taste of change, if compared to the usual, very expectable type of service. Although first usual habits and our comfort zone is first, purposely challenged by David Munoz, I settled and enjoyed living a new and what I knew would be a unique experience. What I mean by "missing target by trying too hard" started when, unfortunately, the actual main purpose of attending a restaurant began : drinking and eating. Choosing a wine (no per glass per course option) that could suit the whole meal is, in my opinion impossible. The variety of tastes and food styles provided is large and therefore one wine only option is an error, which unfortunately no-one can avoid, unless you decide to stick to water (which may have been the best idea thinking back). On the food front, David Munoz demonstrates his extremely strong and unique identity by proposing a menu where he clearly intends to show and share all that goes on in his creative mind. Now this creativity is great, only that it totally lacks organising and ordering, as well as electing, and therefore leaving out, some dishes or courses. In short, the set meal (there are 2 but both lead to the same issue) is just a succession of courses, which does not have any logic, taste-wise, even diet-wise, and is, even in the short menu case, too long by 2-3 courses (out of 8). Another point, even more worrying to me, is the deliberate choice of some cooking techniques (especially to deliver fish), which simply taste awfuly bad and sickening. This makes the meal surprise you nicely at a few points along the journey, but because of these cooking techniques mistakes (I cannot see what else it could be) and the far too long series of dishes not making any logic sense in the way they are sequenced, one ends up far too full far too quickly. Add the impossible wine selection on top that cannot help eating all this because no good fit is possible.  Feeling sick is what happens there and this is a real shame for a place like this. This is what I mean by trying too hard. Unfortunately, It is impossible that one gets to taste all that the chef has in his creative mind, therefore stricter and more thought through choice must be made in order to give sense to the experience.

title_review: At the end of the day, disappointing
review_preview: Creative, inventive, sometimes startling, fun... all of these.  But delicious?  No.  The atmosphere, although somewhat stark, is restful and the tables are far apart assuring privacy.  The service is impeccable.  The wine list can be overwhelming but there is a very helpful page of recommended...
review_full: Creative, inventive, sometimes startling, fun... all of these. But delicious? No. The atmosphere, although somewhat stark, is restful and the tables are far apart assuring privacy. The service is impeccable. The wine list can be overwhelming but there is a very helpful page of recommended wines for all price ranges. Ramon came by and made us feel welcome. We ordered the mid-range "experience" menu. We agree with other reviewers about the amount of food. Each dish is small but they do add up. My strategy was not to finish everything but still... By the end of the meal we were almost begging them to stop bringing dishes. The bottom line is that although it was all flawlessly prepared, it was just not delicious. The flavors were interesting, contrasting, and sometimes odd. But not the kind of food where you want to savor each bite. I won't give up on Michelin starred restaurants but I wouldn't choose this one again.

review_full: We ate at Oliveto last night and it will be one our favorite memories from this trip. It's a block from one of the main roads, tucked away from the throngs of tourists, with only 25 seats. As is typical of American tourists, we were there early at 8:30 p.m. when they opened. The host (who also served as our waiter) was quiet, but very friendly and helpful, particularly in addressing the gluten free needs of one of our party members. The food was simply delicious and beautifully presented. Two in our party shared a large salad that included sun dried tomatoes, roasted eggplant, cherry tomatoes, lettuce and mozzarella. Another had a seared tuna, cooked just right, while I had their pasta with pear and Gorgonzola cheese, plated on an Parmesan basket. The desserts were equally delicious. A simply wonderful meal overall.

title_review: Amazing gourmet twist on pinxtos with friendly staff/owners
review_preview: We just had the greatest time eating and talking with the staff/owners there. The menu is amazing with a variety of gourmet, fusión type tapas. They also have English menus and they speak English really well, though we had more fun talking in Spanish. We...
review_full: We just had the greatest time eating and talking with the staff/owners there. The menu is amazing with a variety of gourmet, fusión type tapas. They also have English menus and they speak English really well, though we had more fun talking in Spanish.  We got the calamares bao, which was what caught our eye in the first place. It was like a bocadillo calamares but with a Chinese bao instead. The bao was perfect and everything you would expect a Bao to be - so white and fluffy. It was actually quite large too, which makes up for the higher price. We also got the Iberian Bacon pinxto. Imagine a huge chunk of pork belly, caramelized on the outside and soft and tender on the inside. Definitely an unexpected highlight. Honestly, if he could add a Bao to that too, it would be heaven. It was pretty empty when we got there so we were also able to chat with who I believe might be the owner. He was so nice, helping us improve our Español while also just getting to know each others backgrounds. Very cool dude and very chill. I would 100% come here again if I ever make it back to madrid.

title_review: THE BEST meal I have had to date
review_preview: WOW, WOW, WOW.  I cannot begin to describe the enchanting experience we had here.  Starting with Ramon himself taking our orders and welcoming us, to the second to none service we received, every moment of the experience must have be carefully master planned by the...
review_full: WOW, WOW, WOW. I cannot begin to describe the enchanting experience we had here. Starting with Ramon himself taking our orders and welcoming us, to the second to none service we received, every moment of the experience must have be carefully master planned by the creative genius behind what is Ramon Freixa. We enjoyed the Experience Menu with Wine Pairing; which is likely more food than you can likely handle, but, trust me, its too good to leave on your plate. Definitely do a tasting menu with a wine pairing, worth every penny and then some. Don't fill up on the bread to much, which is hard to do considering its taste and freshness. This is a must visit restaurant. Only 35 seats so make a reservation.  This is an experience, and I do not want to spoil it for you with details of what we enjoyed, just know that you are in for a real treat, which will likely rank as one of the best you will ever have. I cannot say enough, just go. I can't wait until I return. Bravo Ramon, Bravo

title_review: A really nice place for good Italian food.

The service was excellent, attentive and friendly but by no means overwhelming. And the food was excellent. We shared a starter or artichokes with Italian ham and tomato sauce (undoubtedly home made) and both enjoyed it. My wife then had pasta stuffed with boletus (marvellous) and I had a tuna steak which was perfect. The selection of wine was not that lengthy, which was not a problem as it contained a few of our favourite (if a little overpriced) labels. All in all, a really enjoyable experience.

In fact, they have every right to call themselves "restaurantino creativo italiano" - not only the food but the design, too, is creative and whimsical, a real joy to observe. As for hospitality in its original sense, owner, staff and girlfriend looked after us with focus, interest, and humour. As said, those guys deserve 6 points!!!! If we had another day, we'd be back exploring the next dishes on the menu!

review_preview: Bite by bite you’ll travel and bite by bite you’ll explore new sensations that you never would have imagined were possible through food alone. It’s something that only Dabiz Muñoz’s creativity can show you. His unique way to interpret the World’s finest and most well...
review_full: Bite by bite you’ll travel and bite by bite you’ll explore new sensations that you never would have imagined were possible through food alone. It’s something that only Dabiz Muñoz’s creativity can show you. His unique way to interpret the World’s finest and most well known dishes will reintroduce you to the classics, like Diverxo’s version of cheese naan, and make you aware of different senses, like the moment you eat sea urchin from your own hand. Whatever the dish, through insightful combinations of unusual ingredients he will bring about an explosion of flavors that awaken new places in your palate. Simply put, you’ve never experienced something like this before and, believe me, once you do get the chance to experience it, you’ll get to value the magic that can be created in the culinary world.

Do try the mushrooms & ham croquetas.

review_preview: We decided to visit Oliveto after reading the positive Tripadvisor reviews and mentions that they  had vegetarian options- always a difficulty in Southern Europe! We visited on a Saturday evening at about 22.00 and had no problem getting a table. We were welcomed by the...
review_full: We decided to visit Oliveto after reading the positive Tripadvisor reviews and mentions that they had vegetarian options- always a difficulty in Southern Europe! We visited on a Saturday evening at about 22.00 and had no problem getting a table. We were welcomed by the manager/ owner who had excellent English and was happy to talk us through the menu, including suggesting what could be customised to be cheese and meat free. The restaurant is small and quirkily decorated- we liked the cheese grater light especially. I ordered a salad, customised with no meat or cheese and extra aubergine, while my partner ordered a Margherita pizza. We also ordered some excellent and cheap Prosecco. We were given a bruschetta starter on the house before our meals arrived. My salad was delicious- big and leafy, with mango and aubergine and a tasty berry dressing- unusual and perfect for the hot weather! Bread and nice oil and vinegar were provided. When we requested the bill the manager offered us a liqueur on the house- a lovely gesture. The bill for two- only 25E.  I would definitely recommend Oliveto to any visitors to Madrid looking for delicious, well presented and unusual Italian food and wonderful service.

title_review: Good, small restaurant--lots of vegetarian options
review_preview: After spending a few weeks eating delicious Spanish food we were ready for a change of palate and were happy to find this restaurant rated high and close to where we were staying.  We arrived right as it opened, but they quickly accommodated us.  The...
review_full: After spending a few weeks eating delicious Spanish food we were ready for a change of palate and were happy to find this restaurant rated high and close to where we were staying.  We arrived right as it opened, but they quickly accommodated us. The decorations are very charming and designed to look like you were at someone's house. The service was welcoming and approachable. The food was good. My daughter is vegetarian and she had lots of options to chose from. She ordered the trofie al pesto (the owner is from Tuscany, and this is a specialty of the region) which was very good. Husband and I ordered seafood plates, though I can't remember what they were, but they were good! They have a good Italian wine list, we ordered proseco and I ordered a class of pinot grigio which was delicious. It was quite hot in there, even though the AC was running, but I know this is something that is characteristic of traveling in Europe in July. I'd go back if I am trying to each something other than Spanish food.  The owner was very friendly and brough us a shot of limoncello before leaving.

Food is very good, not a delicious treat but really really good and was served very fast. title_review: Authentic Italian in a casual atmosphere
review_preview: I had heard great things about this small Italian restaurant two minutes from the Reina Sofia art museum, and I was pleasantly surprised by how authentic the food and atmosphere was.  It is a slice of Italy in Madrid.My friend and I both ordered...
review_full: I had heard great things about this small Italian restaurant two minutes from the Reina Sofia art museum, and I was pleasantly surprised by how authentic the food and atmosphere was. It is a slice of Italy in Madrid. My friend and I both ordered a pizza, which were excellent. First of all, for me, the key is the dough, which was cooked perfectly on the bottom and wasn't to thin, which seems to be the case in many pizzerias in Madrid. The mozzarella was gooey and fresh. I ordered La Locura, which has pieces of bacon and rucula spread over the top. The size of the pizza was perfect for one person, filling but so much that you feel like immediately going home and taking a siesta. The price is 10.50€. We ordered a glass of the Sangiovese red for 2.60€, which was average but good. The service was excellent, and the atmosphere was like a small bistro in a neighborhood of Roma, for example. A nice touch was when the chef came out to ask all of the diners how everything was. I look forward to going back and trying one of the pasta dishes, which I saw the table next to us eating, and the size of the portion looked just right as well. I would recommend this restaurant to Italian food lovers who are looking for any pretentious or expensive.

We had pizza, whole wheat ravioli, little purse shaped pasta with Gorgonzola and pears and a salad with mango. It was probably the best meal we ate in Spain. The waitress was friendly and the service great. If/when we return to Madrid we will be certain to return!

review_preview: Went to Ramón Freixa on my most recent trip to Madrid with my mom. We kind of have made it a must to visit Michelin rated restaurants while abroad, so we have some others to compare it to. We had the "Experience Menu" which included...
review_full: Went to Ramón Freixa on my most recent trip to Madrid with my mom. We kind of have made it a must to visit Michelin rated restaurants while abroad, so we have some others to compare it to. We had the "Experience Menu" which included 20 courses. First of all, there is no doubt that the food is superb and the quality of it outstanding, if you're a foodie, you will definitely have a good time here enjoying some delicious combinations of food. The service is very attentive, but most important, nice and engaging. Servers really tried to connect with us during our visit, which made dinner much more pleasant. However, there is a reason why the place has two michelin stars and not three, I did not felt "culinary perfection" in all of the bites taken that night. (For me, this does not necessarily has to happen in a Michelin rated restaurant, it well could be in a coffee shop or casual restaurant, although Michelin places get close enough) Some plates I would rate as just "ok", but the majority are exquisite. It still has room to grow and perfect flavor. Be sure to try the butter bread from Ramón's father, it is amazing. Decor is contemporary and the ambience inviting. You will have a good time here.

Combinations I had never thought of. I went with a discount from the usual web sites, that wasn't applicable for a menu. Ramon himself came out and asked our preferences and organized a menu for us. I thought, oh dear. A way to avoid the discount.  I was wrong. We received a menu of maybe 12 dishes and had a discount. I met Ramon. I had possibly the best meal in Spain for 3 years (that is saying a lot. The quality here is high) and never had the feeling of pretentious waiters or snooty staff. It was a pleasure. Plates by Versace (I think). Food personally selected by Ramon and ok, a price that matches a good meal. But well worth it as an experience.  Normally I don't review expensive restaurants as they have a marketing budget, but I. This case it didn't feel expensive until you tasted the food. It was wonderful.  Anyway. 5 stars!

review_preview: Diverxo's new venue is breathtaking. It looks like someone has designed their dream restaurant, complete with curtains that can enclose every table (bit like a hospital bed - sorry, but true), amazing lighting and a very interesting workspace in the centre of the room. Oh,...
review_full: Diverxo's new venue is breathtaking. It looks like someone has designed their dream restaurant, complete with curtains that can enclose every table (bit like a hospital bed - sorry, but true), amazing lighting and a very interesting workspace in the centre of the room. Oh, and the flying pigs have had a makeover too. This was my fourth time at Diverxo and my first time at the new place. The menu was spectacular, of course, but I can't help wishing that chef Dabiz would try to stop out-doing himself. I think he has reached a level now which he should just maintain instead of trying to better.  Because it wasn't any better than any previous time. Just weirder.  I don't mind weird, but when things just don't make sense I lose interest. And this menu didn't make sense. It got so vague in the middle that we were just baffled. And not in a good way. When the curtains were wrapped around our table and the music box appeared in the centre of the table with 1970s French music we just wondered what was going on. We had covered dishes in front of us which we weren't allowed to touch and a waiter beside each of us, making us really uncomfortable, just staring at us. Then they went "okay you can eat now." It was just so random. There were thirteen different parts to that dish. It was just too much. The staff, and especially the chef, still have the same level of arrogance as usual and didn't want to serve me the longest tasting menu because I don't eat seafood. We advised when we made the booking months beforehand that I don't eat seafood and that we would like the long tasting menu. At any other restaurant it would have been no problem. But here the customer doesn't decide what they eat. (We did manage to get the long tasting menu in the end - they just took off the seafood. Why couldn't they do that in the first place?) They have changed the "costumes" that the waiting staff wear. If they didn't look bad before, they look like escaped convicts now. And the service was so chaotic (I think that's on purpose) that there was no way to relax at all. Despite everything I have said, I have given five stars and at 200€ per person excl. drinks (and therefore being the most expensive tasting menu in Madrid now) I still think it was good value. This was my fourth time at Diverxo and I would go back. But it's not high on my list after this latest experience.

review_full: This restaurant have modern, almost perfect marketing. It sells this restaurant as something extravagant, special, unique, controversial, drugged. In real, you will get childish interior, funny waiters and mainly, disgusting food. Just to clarify, I visited most of top or three michelin restaurants like El Bulli, Noma, Roca's etc. and also most of Asia's countries, so statement it's modern asia gastronomy (we were told this by a waiter after we wanted less pepper, which is exaggerated in almost every dish), but this is like if young child is trying to be in world of adults. Ok, a plus for chef is he is doing it in your own way, that's positive, but it's only positive and it's like if a musical group doing funny things on stage, but music itself is poor. For example, we got a soup in medical test-tube or sauce given in medical syringe; is anyone still hungry? Or, we got horseradish in a foam. So what? I think I'm against most of reviewers, but this is so obsolete. Even if you accept the bizarre interior (after all, why not), time of molecular gastronomy is over for many years now and various ingredients together are absolutely not working here. Above all, we have unpleasant diarrhoea next day and we felt like we were abused to this nonsensical experiment, created by young child.

title_review: I have absolutely no idea of what I ate... And it was the best dinner of my life
review_preview: If you're food adventurous, this is a must go... But if you're the kind of person who has many allergies or food restrictions, then you should maybe try somewhere else...We tried making a reservation on this restaurant as soon as we got to Madrid,...
review_full: If you're food adventurous, this is a must go... But if you're the kind of person who has many allergies or food restrictions, then you should maybe try somewhere else... We tried making a reservation on this restaurant as soon as we got to Madrid, but it was full until like February... BUT there was a cancellation and I guess we insisted so much they called us! This restaurant recently got it's third Michelin star and it's pretty much the place to be in Madrid right now... And if you're planning on going to Spain, MAKE this reservation, you won't regret it. The atmosphere is weird and as we got there, there was a light smoke all over the place, which was probably the worst thing about this experience, but it didn't affect our overall impression It's a degustation menu, you can choose between the 7 and the 11 courses menu (and the whole table has to choose the same amount of courses). The food is fusion and you must go there knowing you'll eat things you have absolutely no idea of what are... I mean, we ate meat and found out it was actually tuna... Yeah, prepare yourself! But this made the dinner even more special. The combinations were like a peace of art, the flavors were rich and the food was refined and delightful! We couldn't decide on what was the best dish... They were all remarkable!  I've been to many 2 and 3 Michelin stars and I just can't take this restaurant off my mind. Best meal I've ever had!  And oh! The 7 courses were enough, but I would suggest that, if you're going to this restaurant, don't eat much on lunch or in the afternoon, make sure you get there starving and order the 11 courses menu. It will be worth all hunger. And it's expensive. BUT also worth the price.

Delicious food, with good advice on the different authentic local dishes - we had baby lamb chops and pork, both utterly delicious with a combination of half raciones to start and some vegetables with our mains. A lovely bottle of Rioja and some coffee to finish rounded off a really great meal. Would definitely eat here again.

review_preview: Went to this restaurant on a flier that we may be able to get in on the first night of a business trip in Madrid.  Fortunately they had a cancellation and we were immediately ushered into the dining room.  Tables are large, yet each is...
review_full: Went to this restaurant on a flier that we may be able to get in on the first night of a business trip in Madrid. Fortunately they had a cancellation and we were immediately ushered into the dining room. Tables are large, yet each is reserved for only one seating. The presentation is great, and the cutlery and plate selection imaginative and corresponds to each dish. We did not have the tasting menu because we were tired from a long day traveling. Nevertheless, our entrees were accompanied by several other matching dishes that were spectacular. It was a memorable meal, and the wine list is extensive and fairly priced. I will definitely be back for a complete tasting meal on a future visit to madrid. Be warned this is modern molecular cuisine. These are numerous small plates, so don't expect a huge plate of food, instead expect to be tantalized with myriad great tastes. Excellent

review_preview: We saved the dinner at Ramon Freixa for our last night in Madrid and were sorely disappointed.  We should have turned back when we entered the restaurant and smelled a horrible sulfur (sewage?) smell.  We mentioned it to the staff who dismissed us.  We grew...
review_full: We saved the dinner at Ramon Freixa for our last night in Madrid and were sorely disappointed. We should have turned back when we entered the restaurant and smelled a horrible sulfur (sewage?) smell. We mentioned it to the staff who dismissed us.  We grew accustomed to it when very unusual food was brought out that had significant smells of their own...when my husband and I each went to the restroom at different time we realized the source of the offensive odor--it was horrible. Some of the was interesting, some looked fine and unique but was so unusual on the palate it was hard to swallow, other items were inedible. One of the worst things was the sherry that was part of the wine pairings.  The lights were extremely bright, service was fine until it was time for the check--which took a very long time. Another couple in the restaurant fell asleep--the entire evening had the feeling of a Robert Altman movie or a Salvador Dali painting.

review_preview: It is hard to lavish enough praise on Ramon Freixa where we recently had a simply sensational 20 course dinner.Ramon himself took our order and as soon as we mentioned we did not eat pig one of the appetizers was immediately whisked away from...
review_full: It is hard to lavish enough praise on Ramon Freixa where we recently had a simply sensational 20 course dinner. Ramon himself took our order and as soon as we mentioned we did not eat pig one of the appetizers was immediately whisked away from our table and replaced - impressive service indeed. Each course is a work of art with some extremely original ideas giving a broad range of textures and tastes, there are some "gimmicks" and overall this was quite a filling meal, the duck liver slice particularly so. Quite simply we enjoyed everything and this cuisine certainly ranks among the best we have tasted in recent years. The wine lists are amazing with some great bins from around the world although we were only interested in Spain and we selected a great "Nelin", a rich white from Clos Magador in Priorat. Coupled with highly interactive staff who all made sure everything went well this was a memorable evening and the best of the four meals we had in Madrid. Very highly recommended.

title_review: The cutting edge of cooking - go have a try!!
review_preview: Diverxo are really striving to push forwards the boundaries of modern cooking.  From the moment I arrived I was being directed and advised on what to do and when to do it.  Surrender to their concept.  Trust their staff.  It is definitely worth it!So......

The meat is the main part? Wrong! Here they were going to mess with my expectations and have me constantly experiencing every dish as it is - not as I expected it to be. review_preview: On Tuesday we went to David Muñoz's Diverxo. Extraordinary. And that's saying something because we got off to a really bad start. Twenty minutes to get a glass of wine ordered from the time we were seated. Then, when asked if I'd like chopsticks to...
review_full: On Tuesday we went to David Muñoz's Diverxo. Extraordinary. And that's saying something because we got off to a really bad start. Twenty minutes to get a glass of wine ordered from the time we were seated. Then, when asked if I'd like chopsticks to which I replied in the affirmative, none ever arrived, but the food transcended all. An amuse bouche of edamame seasoned, perhaps with sumac and something else with a buttermilk-like garlic dipping sauce. Then we both had the seven course tasting menu (the other choice being the thirteen course menu). The seven courses were actually around eleven since a course would often be divided into two halves served sequentially, like the poached prawn (it was called something else) that arrived followed by the grilled, seasoned, head and body with the juices from the body drizzled over the poached tail. Somewhere in the middle were white asparagus wrapped in the skin of red mullet - actually the meal involved parts of red mullet in several of the dishes, such as a pate of red mullet liver on a thin crisp. The courses that I sort of remember include the soup served in a young coconut shell where eating the coconut meat was a desired part of the experience, a steamed roll with a quail's egg yolk barely poached on top, an extraordinary piece of tuna cheek that tasted like a sous-vide cooked short rib, and a piece of ox cheek that had been slow roasted for 112 hours, a small piece of hake served sauced accompanied by a horseradish cream and spherified lime, and a desert which I no longer remember. Very, very highly recommended.

review_preview: I went to Diverxo today for a business lunch. I chose it simply by searching the TripAdvisor map for this part of town. I have just had one of the best gastronomic experiences ever. Once I got past the sticker shock (95 euros for the...
review_full: I went to Diverxo today for a business lunch. I chose it simply by searching the TripAdvisor map for this part of town. I have just had one of the best gastronomic experiences ever. Once I got past the sticker shock (95 euros for the short menu and 137 euros for the long menu), the fun began. The service is exceptional if not somewhat overstaffed (every person seemed to have one specific job - e.g. the lemon zester guy, the last-minute-sauce guy, the napkin folder guy, etc.) Everyone is multilingual, pleasant and informative. In fact, if we left a few items on the plate they seemed sincerely concerned with whether or not we liked it. The presentations are varied and innovative. The food...wow. The kitchen challenges anything your palate has ever expected from a particular ingredient. Seafood, fish, meats, vegetables, sauces all presented spectacularly, colourfully, artistically - but most importantly - the tastes are outstanding. My guest and I walked away from one of the most pleasant dining experiences ever. I look forward to topping this experience, but apparently, I have to wait Until Pigs Fly.

title_review: HANDS DOWN BEST DINING EXPERIENCE IN MADRID
review_preview: Diverxo goes beyond being a restaurant, to the absolute pinnacle of food. This is a DINING EXPERIENCE and not just a meal. My wife and I had already been to the "old" Diverxo where the food was excellent. However, the new restaurant combines the tremendous...
review_full: Diverxo goes beyond being a restaurant, to the absolute pinnacle of food. This is a DINING EXPERIENCE and not just a meal. My wife and I had already been to the "old" Diverxo where the food was excellent. However, the new restaurant combines the tremendous talents of Chef David Muñoz with a decor that is heavenly, outstanding waitstaff, and everything's else that you need to be three star restaurant. Muñoz combines obscure and little used ingredients with a sublime touch that is the thing of genius. This is food that will knock your socks off and leave you wishing that the night never ends. Madrileños often say "from Madrid to Heavan..." I think it should actually be "de Diverxo al Cielo..." We can't wait to go back. PS don't let the price scare you, this is a restaurant worth every single cent.

P.S. better lunch than dinner since the location is not very romantic let's say, and the portion is normal, so you would leave there very satisfied and probably you need more time to digest your stomach and thought.

review_preview: What a wonderful experience!  My wife and I had an amazing dinner at La Mi Vent during our last night in Madrid.  The ambiance is unique and inviting, from the old wood fired oven to the comfy bar to the dining area in the old...
review_full: What a wonderful experience! My wife and I had an amazing dinner at La Mi Vent during our last night in Madrid. The ambiance is unique and inviting, from the old wood fired oven to the comfy bar to the dining area in the old downstairs wine cellar. On of the most delicious, and simple, things I have ever had is their complimentary soup made with iberico pork bones - just wonderful and inviting. We started with one of their iberico charcuterie plates, which did not disappoint. It included some traditional iberico ham, chorizo, a salami type sausage and some beef ham with some manchego - all extremely good. We also had the pan con tomate, which was just okay. It was served differently as the Cristal bread was served separately from the tomato (which we we're not really into), and the bread was overly toasted. Our main course was terrific - grilled iberico pork served on anhot, sizzling plater with padron peppers (yum!), and potatoes. The pork was some of the best I've had. It was cooked perfectly, with a wonderful sear and flavor. I would eat this dish every day.  Desert fell flat however. We tried torrija de toffee which was just much to sweet - tasty but much, much to sweet for our tastes. The wine list is really nice, with many different types, regions and costs available. I also need to mention their house olive oil - wow. I have never had an olive oil quite like it. We ended up buying a bottle to bring back with us. The service was spot on - attentive, polite and well versed in the menu. La Mi Venta is a must stop when in Madrid!

review_preview: Each year I try to outdo my previous attempts to make my wife's birthday a magical experience and each year I just about manage to do so.This year we booked a last minute trip to Madrid and unfortunately Roman's restaurant was fully booked for...
review_full: Each year I try to outdo my previous attempts to make my wife's birthday a magical experience and each year I just about manage to do so. This year we booked a last minute trip to Madrid and unfortunately Roman's restaurant was fully booked for dinner - however, lunch was a possibility. I had pinned my hopes on dinner so it was with trepidation that I booked lunch. Our generous hosts booked us into the private room where the two of us could enjoy dinner in solitude. My wife was delighted, going to Ramon's restaurant had already been in her mind (despite my best attempts to disguise my plan) and the private experience had been a wonderful surprise. Given our tricky diets (vegetarian/vegan/pescatarian), I had arranged for us to enjoy a simple menu, hopeful that this would enough for us to enjoy Ramon's excellent creations. Well, this clearly was not going to work for Ramon who joined us in the private room and enquired what we would like to enjoy for lunch. My wife, who is not often lost for words, was speechless. A long time admirer of his work she was almost beside herself with excitement. We enjoyed an eleven course marvel of creation, from cheese eggs to bubbly sangria. I would love to go into the detail that would justify the tastes but it's simply not possible, certainly the best gastronomic experience that we have ever enjoyed. Two bottles of wine, eleven incredible courses and 4 hours with our ever attentive hosts. The restaurant tried to put a price on this but it was well under what it will be worth to us in memories over the coming years.

title_review: Book early, come hungry, enjoy a superb meal
review_preview: This is outstanding restaurant, but before I get to that, there are a few preliminaries.  There are only about 20 seats in the restaurant and there is only one serving.  The meal is an experience to savor so plan for 3-3.5 hours.  As a result,...
review_full: This is outstanding restaurant, but before I get to that, there are a few preliminaries.  There are only about 20 seats in the restaurant and there is only one serving.  The meal is an experience to savor so plan for 3-3.5 hours.  As a result, reservations well in advance are required.  Once you have secured a reservation it is time to think about preparation.  There are two sides to the menu.  On the left is a la carte, and on the right the chef's tasting menu.  You will not need to read the left side. The right side is were the experience resides.  There are three tasting menus.  For ease of reference, I will call them small medium and large.  Small means don't eat lunch.  Medium means skip breakfast and lunch.  Large means start your fast after lunch the previous day.  The wine list is extensive, and unless you can get through War and Peace in an afternoon, ignore it.  Go with the master's wine pairings.  We did this to avoid the wine list, but primarily to get a variety of wines that would complement the food.  The pairings are outstanding and well worth the price--all great quality.  A couple Of them I intend to put my wine merchant on the hunt for once we return home.  Now to the meal.  As mentioned above, prepare for an experience not just a meal.  There were at least three introductory dishes before the first appetizer course.  All were 3 bites at the most but the tastes were bliss.  Items that I would never have thought to put on the same plate, presented in an artistic fashion on custom shaped dish ware.  At this point, I already knew that the wine pairings was the correct route.  Through the next five courses, each split into multiple sub courses, probably 15-20 plates in all, we had experienced tastes that were just unbelievable.  This is not an inexpensive endeavor, but one would not expect it to be given the two Michelin stars and the Quality of the product.  Nonetheless, it was well worth it.  Please remember, reserve early and come hungry to avoid disappointment.

review_preview: Together with six senior Madrileños plotting the downfall of Spain's new King, a business man and his mistress plus two other couples we lunched at this elegantly comfortable restaurant. The chef, Ramon Freixa himself, was present and took our order. Magic ensued. But, lets be...
review_full: Together with six senior Madrileños plotting the downfall of Spain's new King, a business man and his mistress plus two other couples we lunched at this elegantly comfortable restaurant. The chef, Ramon Freixa himself, was present and took our order. Magic ensued. But, lets be clear, there were no clouds of dried ice "smoke", obscure jellied objects or other special effects. No, the magic lay in the mouthwatering dishes, all of which came is some form of disguise or other. The servings were plentiful, beautifully presented with clear explanations from the waiters. The service was excellent, the table impeccable, the experience magic. If you fancy a giant paella or a big fat steak and chips you should probably not bother coming here. For us it was a meal and a restaurant to treasure and remember.

title_review: Did chef Ramon take our order?
review_preview: After visiting a number of Michelin starred restaurants that carry the chef names, it would be our first time seeing a master chef (we believe he's chef Ramon himself) going to each table and took the orders.  Because we wanted a lighter lunch and of...
review_full: After visiting a number of Michelin starred restaurants that carry the chef names, it would be our first time seeing a master chef (we believe he's chef Ramon himself) going to each table and took the orders. Because we wanted a lighter lunch and of course not to spend too much, we chose the short menu and being a bit starstruck and I spoke for the table "We just want the short menu". The chef replied politely "That's ok!". I was satisfied, humbled and honoured by someone who truly loved and cared about his craft. I could only described our lunch experience by calling it a culinary adventure. Every bit was an unique experience that challenged our senses. Even the in house baked bread was as good as any top bakeries in Paris. The bread was so good that I ordered three even though I only wanted one to save room. My kids also had a great time not only because of the food, they were especially amused by the synchronized serving that resembled a dance move. At the end, we were completely satisfied and our lunch was simply the best meal we had during our two weeks stay in Spain. The experience was surprisingly down to earth given it's Michelin 2 stars status. e.g. I had two classes of wine (1 dry white and 1 dry red which I trusted the server to select), I was charged for an extremely reasonable 9 euros each with refill, as compared to recently that I was charged almost 60 pounds for 2 wines with similar quality at restaurant G.R. in Chelsea, England. With a meal so close to perfection, I would like to offer a few minor suggestions or comments: 1) With an Asian background, I could not help but the eat the Nori sitting below the Thai coconut even though it may be an garnish. I did find the Nori a bit stale. A Japanese chef once shows me that a quick roast of nori over open flame will bring it back to life. 2) Both the main courses Canelonni and Socarrat were flawless, but they were both very large portions. Somehow the table next to us knew to split the Socarrat to share for 2 people, and I thought it would make it perfect as I felt very quilty in wasting such fine food which lead me to overeat.

Attention to quality is to me the most important detail at any restaurant and it seems to be the highest priority here. The menu is ample and varied and the flavors demonstrate the worthiness of the two Michelin stars this owner has received. Service is superb and friendly. review_preview: My husband and I enjoy a variety of food experiences, from a tasty Buffalo wing and other bar foods and holes-in-the-wall, or fancy pants, locally sourced eclectic (but basically French/American) restaurants (there are a ton of these in New York). What we don't like is...
review_full: My husband and I enjoy a variety of food experiences, from a tasty Buffalo wing and other bar foods and holes-in-the-wall, or fancy pants, locally sourced eclectic (but basically French/American) restaurants (there are a ton of these in New York). What we don't like is kitschy and something more cerebral than tasty. At first, reading up on Diverxo, I was worried this was more of the latter. But the menu and descriptions of the dishes sounded like foods we would enjoy, so we took a risk and booked a lunch during our visit in March 2013.  It was quite a bit out of the way, a train ride out to the suburbs. We got there early and spent 25 minutes wandering a half-empty mercado. When we were seated, they handed us this flier, printed on silver cardstock paper, that had some diatribe about embracing life and all it's unexpected surprises, something about a roller coaster taking you up and down and all around. Again, I was feeling a tad worried. There were also sculptures of flying pigs, with feathery wings, on every table. This did not worry me; they were very cute. The first dish came - wow, edamame! Really, not that wow, I eat bags of this stuff at home. But the sauce was interesting and so we dug in. Then came our utensils for our next course--a spatula! I wondered if they were going to make us make our own food, as part of the roller coaster ride. But instead we were instructed to eat with it, and we discovered that next to chopsticks, it was one of the most ingenious ways to eat. Spoons and fish knives were shamed. What followed were a series of beautifully plated, delicious courses, or rather canvases (they serve them on flat canvases, sometimes "painting" on the sauces). There was a little slightly briney seafood bouillabaise with small crab pile on the side, a fish covered in a light foie gras sauce, some kind of space-age looking dim sum dumpling with a carrot puree, a very weird but ultimately good combination of grilled squid and strawberry (roller coaster go down, weee!), a cod that was cooked and braised to imitate a hearty rabbit stew, and a piece of beef tongue that was slowly cooked for 8 hours (patience, young paduwan). Also, we should talk about the wine. It was lunch, so we wanted to keep it to a couple glasses each. I asked if I could start with a glass of white, and our sommelier (poor guy had to wear this silver shiny shirt) came by, opened a bottle, and placed it in an ice bucket. I thought I had mispoken and accidentally ordered a bottle! But after I finished my white, he came and asked if I would like a different glass of wine. Why, yes. So he opened up a red for me and poured a glass that paired excellently with my later courses. I was floored that they would open up bottles for their by-the-glass customers. Very nice, very classy. And very affordable! Each glass was about 6.5 Euro. I would definitely ride this roller coaster again.

review_full: Our experience was far different than the negative reviews. The dining room is small, about 6 or 7 tables. The tables are huge (by American Standards) plenty of room for multiple plates which is how the courses are served. Chef takes the order, and then multiple servers and Sommelier present and serve each course. There are 3 or so amuse course consisting of multiple different bites. Different tasting menu style that ABaC or Roca Moo in Barcelona. Their are really only 3 savory courses served, but each consists of multiple plates and takes on the "featured ingredient". The tomato course had multiple textures and preparations presented on 3 or 4 plates. Food was great. Service was not as good as other similar Michelin restaurants. Plates were not served and presented at the same time. Just slightly less attention to detail. Overall food, room and interesting presentation were excellent.

title_review: Skillful chef should stick to the basics.
review_preview: The food at this Michelin two-star restaurant is ultra fancy:   for instance, melted cheese disguised as a rock, printed paper that can be eaten.   Most dishes have multiple elements served separately.  The problem is that the more elaborate and interesting the presentation, the worse the...
review_full: The food at this Michelin two-star restaurant is ultra fancy: for instance, melted cheese disguised as a rock, printed paper that can be eaten. Most dishes have multiple elements served separately. The problem is that the more elaborate and interesting the presentation, the worse the taste. To be precise, most of what was served was barely edible. The three exceptions were the three simplest dishes: a 3-star veal shank, a 3-star fish soup (but not its contents or its side dishes), and various 3-star breads made in Barcelona by the chef's father. If the chef would (at the risk perhaps of losing favor with Michelin) reorient his cooking to the basics, he could have a 3-star restaurant; a reviewer once made the comment that a great dish at Taillevant was chicken cooked simply. As it is, in my opinion, he barely has a 1-star restaurant, and that only, in my experience, because of the three dishes mentioned above.

title_review: One of the best meals on the last trip...
review_preview: Contrary to what the last review says we had an absolutely fantastic experience at the restaurant.The maitre d' (from Bulgaria, unfortunately we drank a lot so forgot his name :) ) was one of the nicest people we have ever had a pleasure of...
review_full: Contrary to what the last review says we had an absolutely fantastic experience at the restaurant. The maitre d' (from Bulgaria, unfortunately we drank a lot so forgot his name :) ) was one of the nicest people we have ever had a pleasure of meeting and we are very thankful for the treatment we have received. Everything we had was pretty amazing, but the suckling pig was out of this world!!! Super crispy and the meat was melt in your mouth tender. The menu does lie a little bit, as we were expecting a ~9 course menu, and in the end we got 15+ courses. We were definitely ready to blow up in the end! The bread is made by Ramon's father in Barcelona and they ship it via high speed train daily....the butter bread was completely addictive!!! Another unique things about this restaurant is that the dinner order was taken by Ramon himself...how often do you see that in fine dining??? The gin/tonic we got in the end was the size of Big Gulp from 7-1-1. Never saw a bigger one in my life...hence we didn't even finish them...and it was a perfect dinner ending at +40C in Madrid that day.

review_preview: Extremely expensive with lousy service. We decided to do something special for my parents 50th wedding anniversary, so we made a reservation for 10, since my brother wanted to join in the celebrations with his family. For starters they said that to take our reservations...
review_full: Extremely expensive with lousy service. We decided to do something special for my parents 50th wedding anniversary, so we made a reservation for 10, since my brother wanted to join in the celebrations with his family. For starters they said that to take our reservations we must adhere to an specific predefined meal, without being able to select anything from the menu or wine list. That should have been enough of a signal, yet since we wanted to treat our parents to a special occasion, we agreed. The day that we had made the reservation my mother (72 years of age) came down with food poisoning and we called to see if we could move the date. They said no, and that they would charge the full amount, if we did not show. Making a great effort we made it arriving 20 minutes late. To our surprise they said they would not honor the full menu and could only serve 2/3 of it, just because we made it 20 minutes late. They did not care my mother had made a great effort just to show up. We insisted that we should be served the full menu, despite talking with the maître and asking to talk to a supervisor they served 2/3 of the proposed menu and included 2 - 16 euro bottles of wine for 10 people. Food was not extraordinary and included pasta and meatballs which frankly you could get at any NY deli for 1/3 the price and as good or better quality. Then the check arrived, they charged us 100 euros per person. Unless you want to get ripped off, stay clear of this restaurant which is all fame, no substance and zero character.

title_review: Great food and service,  what else
review_preview: Visited there with 3 other friends.  We had to book it well in advance and we only had 2 nights in Madrid so I was really happy that they could book us in.  This was our choice for the Michelline star experience dinner in Madrid...
review_full: Visited there with 3 other friends. We had to book it well in advance and we only had 2 nights in Madrid so I was really happy that they could book us in. This was our choice for the Michelline star experience dinner in Madrid and we were right. It was great, service was excellent, food was unique tasty and an experience. It show cased best produce of Spain with pride. Entire experience was not molecular gastronomy but you had glimpses of many different schools of cooking, with rock looking cheese . . . 10 different steles of tomatos and an amazing hearty main meal. One of the most important tips that I can give you is go with the wine matching, it is excellent value for what you will get. For an extra 20-30 dollars per head you are going to end up trying wine you will never tried before. Highly recommended.

title_review: Mejor comida en mi viaje! Best food in my trip
review_preview: No les puedo recomendar este restaurante más! Comenzando con la ensalada Doré (verdes, salmón, aguacate y vinagre balsámico), una paella de mariscos (para 2 personas) la tarta de limón, café y un shot de baileys. No se arrepentirán de venir. Nuestro mesero Miguel Alejandro también...
review_full: No les puedo recomendar este restaurante más! Comenzando con la ensalada Doré (verdes, salmón, aguacate y vinagre balsámico), una paella de mariscos (para 2 personas) la tarta de limón, café y un shot de baileys. No se arrepentirán de venir. Nuestro mesero Miguel Alejandro también fue excelente. I can't recommend this restaurant enough! I had the Doré salad (greens, salmon and avocados with balsamic vinegar), seafood paella (for two), lemon tart, coffee and baileys. You wont regret coming here. The staff was also very welcoming. Our server Miguel Alejandro was vey attentive and excellent at his job.  Le service était excellent. Je vous recommande ce restaurant. J'ai commandé la salade Doré (du saumon, d'avocats et du vinaigre balsamique), paella de fruit de mer (pour deux), de la tarte de citron, du café et du baileys. Les serveurs étaient très attentifs, spécifiquement Miguel Alejandro, le nôtre.

review_preview: The only reservation we could get during the time of our three-day stay in Madrid was Friday lunchtime.  There is limited seating at this restaurant so be sure to reserve well in advance.  The dining room is beautiful, with large windows onto a patio/garden.  The...
review_full: The only reservation we could get during the time of our three-day stay in Madrid was Friday lunchtime. There is limited seating at this restaurant so be sure to reserve well in advance. The dining room is beautiful, with large windows onto a patio/garden. The place settings, ornate with gold service plates, are just the beginning of being presented with beautiful china, different in style and colour throughout the entire meal. Everything has been thought of carefully here so that your entire experience, visually as well as senses and tastes, is pure bliss. Our menu was well balanced with many delicious "beginnings" such as breaded seaweed, melon with capers but it was the ball of foie that exploded in my mouth that stays with me and yes, the bread is superb but then so was the confit suckling pig and the red mullet.... and on it goes. The cheese dish was one of the most interesting presentations of excellent cheeses I have had the occasion to try.  Ramon Freixa took the orders and I agree, it is nice to know the chef is "home". There are too many chefs these days who have over-extended themselves to other towns, other ideas. The service was a delight and long may we be able to enjoy this wonderful restaurant.

title_review: Impeccable Service and Creative, Delicious Meal
review_preview: Where do I start... First of all, there is a reason this guy is Michelin starred (I thought he had two, but someone told me he just garnered his third...). Your palate is in for a treat at this place. What impressed me most of...
review_full: Where do I start... First of all, there is a reason this guy is Michelin starred (I thought he had two, but someone told me he just garnered his third...). Your palate is in for a treat at this place. What impressed me most of all is that Ramon himself is present. Not off giving lectures in China or making a reality TV show. He is constantly wandering from the kitchen into the small (7 or 8 tables) dining room, conversing with his diners, making sure everyone is happy, etc.  The service is probably the finest I have seen anywhere. A small wait staff of 4 young, impeccably dressed (NOT white shirts and black pants, but rather blue blazers, ties, khakis) men. This dining room runs like a well oiled machine. Not a beat is missed, these guys are PROFESSIONAL. They all work all of the tables, so you get a chance to chat with all four of them. One recommended a fantastic Spanish white wine that was perfect. The food is presented so perfectly that is practically tells a story, and the flavors and combinations are simply divine. All in all, the tasting menu spans the horizon of food groups, flavors, textures and colors.  I have eaten in many fine establishments around the world, Michelin starred and not. And let me tell you, this is one of the top five meals I have ever eaten. If you have ever been to Comerç 24 in Barcelona, another incredible dining experience, this place rates on a par. DO NOT MISS!!!

review_preview: Visited for dinner with family and friends. The bread and butter, I have to say will remain in my memory for ever. Some of the best bread I have had I my life! I would go back there just for the bread. The Love and...
review_full: Visited for dinner with family and friends. The bread and butter, I have to say will remain in my memory for ever. Some of the best bread I have had I my life! I would go back there just for the bread. The Love and Hate Oyster dish was amazingly delicious and this is coming from someone who is not particularly fond of oysters. The scallops, scorpion fish, and the stag loin were all great. Desserts were really good, especially the chocolate and saffron. Though there are better fine dining restaurants in Madrid, this one is worth it for the price and the food and wine selection. Definitely recommended.

title_review: Excellent food, service, and ambience - a great dinner in Madrid
review_preview: My wife and I were looking for a great place to sit down and eat a nice dinner and really fill up - not to sound gluttonous, but after days of eating tapas meal after meal, we wanted something hearty.  It was our last night...
review_full: My wife and I were looking for a great place to sit down and eat a nice dinner and really fill up - not to sound gluttonous, but after days of eating tapas meal after meal, we wanted something hearty. It was our last night in Madrid and the reviews for La Mi Venta convinced us to give it a try. I booked the reservation online and requested The Cave, their underground cellar which has room for only five or six tables. We were seated promptly when we arrived and the service was great - very polite, helpful, and thankfully spoke English well as our Spanish is mediocre on a good day. We started with grilled vegetables and a bottle of wine. We each ordered an entree (steak for me, lamb chops for her) and finished with their chocolate mousse and their complimentary liqueur to wrap everything up. The bill was very reasonable for three courses and a bottle of wine for two.  We left fat and happy after a great dining experience. Thanks La Mi Venta! We'll visit again when we come back to Madrid.

review_preview: This unassuming litre restaurant with a few tables on the pavement was only a few minutes from our hotel so, tired & hungry on our first night, we sat down outside for a drink so we could plan where to go to eat. So very...
review_full: This unassuming litre restaurant with a few tables on the pavement was only a few minutes from our hotel so, tired & hungry on our first night, we sat down outside for a drink so we could plan where to go to eat. So very glad we did. Then, later, looking it up in Trip Advisor, we were so pleased with ourselves for having "found it" without any outside help! That first night we ordered a drink first & it came with a delicious tapa of tuna. We ended up staying for another drink & ordered mixed pinchos to share. Couldn't believe it when the slate platter was brought over. Hake with caramelised onions, tuna with sweet tomatoes, lomo with mushrooms, & pate with goats cheese. Best pinchos ever! So it became our "local" restaurant during our stay in Madrid. Although we ate other places too (& had some very good food), we did return to La Mi Venta another twice. We never reserved, and we always sat outside (reservation is pretty much essential for inside), and we were not dsappointed with any of the food. The main dishes are as well thought out & prepared as the tapas, the wines were good, and the waiters were so friendly but really knew their jobs too - a very well run little restaurant. One I would recommend to anyone I knew who was going to be in Madrid.

review_preview: We went there for lunch after some serious shopping in the Salamanca area. The interiors were simple and elegantly decorated.The Chef came over to take our orders. No smile, no welcome but the typical take order and bye sort of attitude. The waiting staff...
review_full: We went there for lunch after some serious shopping in the Salamanca area.  The interiors were simple and elegantly decorated. The Chef came over to take our orders. No smile, no welcome but the typical take order and bye sort of attitude. The waiting staff all looked anxious and stiff with their nose in the air. I understand we were not regulars but tourists. Having said that shouldn’t service be part of the dining experience especially for a two-stars?  My main course was the tiniest portion I have had. Though I have to say the lobster was the sweetest meat ever. My dining partner’s pork was tasty and well presented. It was not one particularly satisfying dining experience among the many Michelin Stars I have visited around the world.

review_full: First meal in Madrid and wow! This place did not disappoint! Food and drink menu were small, but did not disappoint in size or flavor. Our server William was amazing, great service and a nice guy. Started off with the sangria, which was AMAZING! Best I've ever had, and even better than any we had in Portugal (and we drank sangria every night). Ordered the ham & cheese croquettes (8 pieces) and mixed root vegetable chips, half order garlic prawns (4), ropa vieja (shredded beef and potatoes), and risotto de boletus (mushroom risotto). Absolutely delicious!!! Complimentary shot given right before the check, perfect way to end the meal. Couldn't have asked for a better first meal in Madrid. Already planning our second visit for drinks and tapas before we leave :) Highly recommend!

review_preview: After tasting a few 1 and 2 stars Michelin restaurants in Barcelona, Valencia and Salamanca in Spain, we had pretty much a good idea of the price and quality of what a 2 stars suppose to be. Ramón Freixa didn’t deliver what a 2 stars...
review_full: After tasting a few 1 and 2 stars Michelin restaurants in Barcelona, Valencia and Salamanca in Spain, we had pretty much a good idea of the price and quality of what a 2 stars suppose to be. Ramón Freixa didn’t deliver what a 2 stars Michelin suppose to offer. I read other reviews and agreed the servers were arrogant, they speak so fast with their accent and didn’t ask for feedback when food were not finished on plates because we didn’t like it. The restaurant opened at 9, we ordered the shorter tasting menu with 20 dishes and we were too sleepy and ask all desserts to come out at once and yet we still couldn’t leave the restaurant until 12:30!!! The table next to us also kept asking how many course was left mid-way of the dinner, by the time we almost finish you can tell most customers were too sleepy and didn’t even bother to make conversation to others on the table. I also agreed with other reviews that only 1-2 dishes were memorable while the rest was disappointing. Charging €150 was steep, almost all the 1 star Michelin we had in Spain offered better quality, price and service.

You don’t want long course - no problem, we will offer you something smaller. Any allergy? We can create same tasty product perfect for you. I ordered the Risotto de Beloteus which had crispy bacon/ham and mushrooms. DELICIOUS. It might have been the best risotto I've ever had. That day was my last day in Madrid but if it wasn't I would have returned another day. My bf had the ropa vieja and said it was very good. We arrived early around 11:50AM so it was just us and one other table. Bread was served with olive oil too. I highly recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: My husband and I had a fabulous lunch experience at this Michelin 2-star restaurant in the Hotel Unico Madrid. The food was wildly inventive, a delight to the senses, and almost too beautiful to eat. Service was extraordinary -- the finest service in a high-end...
review_full: My husband and I had a fabulous lunch experience at this Michelin 2-star restaurant in the Hotel Unico Madrid. The food was wildly inventive, a delight to the senses, and almost too beautiful to eat. Service was extraordinary -- the finest service in a high-end restaurant that we can remember. As is the custom in Spain, dining is a leisurely affair -- and doubly so at this gastronomic jewel. So plan your time accordingly. And since the restaurant has only six tables, advance reservations would be a must. Bonus Fact: This dining treat costs a fraction of what you would pay for a comparable experience in New York or San Francisco.

title_review: stunning lunch, very friendly and professionally done
review_preview: Delightful.  Ramon Freixa introduced himself personally, and discussed the menu with us.  We had the 110 euro tasting menu, which Ramon changed for my partner who eats no meat (we had warned them in advance by email, but were surprised and pleased that they remembered...
review_full: Delightful. Ramon Freixa introduced himself personally, and discussed the menu with us. We had the 110 euro tasting menu, which Ramon changed for my partner who eats no meat (we had warned them in advance by email, but were surprised and pleased that they remembered - most places don't). We then had a series of excellent tastes and surprises, with the matched wine pairings, plus some Cava as an apero. Charming staff throughout. We left full, happy, and a little drunk, after about 3 hours. Of course you have to be in the mood for this sort of Michelin fussiness, and cooking at this level is never cheap. But if you are in the mood, its as a good 2 star Michelin lunch as we have ever had - and we have had a few.

Our tableware was exquisite as was the help we had with choice of food and wines - the sommelier found for us one of the best godello wines from Ribera Sacra we have tasted.  The food is true fine dining and we appreciated being asked upfront about allergies and dislikes. The food presentations were superb as was the bread - in fact, this was the "best" bread we have eaten in Spain over three weeks. The dishes came at a reasonable pace and we had enough time to savour each course. The spectacle and flavour was there  each time. Highly recommended!h

review_preview: TA reviews were definitely more than accurate. Hidden gem, just five minute walk from our hotel, very welcome because we had an early flight the next morning. The ambience, surroundings and most importantly, fantastic food. Beautiful table in the basement which is has stunning open...
review_full: TA reviews were definitely more than accurate. Hidden gem, just five minute walk from our hotel, very welcome because we had an early flight the next morning. The ambience, surroundings and most importantly, fantastic food. Beautiful table in the basement which is has stunning open brick walls and a very intimate feel. Would recommend booking. We were made to feel so welcome and very prompt service. Bread and an outstanding olive oil provided, followed by a ham soup amuse-bouche. Our waiter Julio spoke superb english and was a credit to the restaurant. He explained the menu and made excellent recommendations. His knowledge was excellent. We picked the traditional tapas to share and then the iberico pork from the grill, also to share. It was outstanding, unlike anything you can get at home. Tapas were generous and very authentic, a real treat. Appreciated that Julio advised us how much to order otherwise we would definitely have overordered! Shared an amazing dessert, which was totally unique. Bread, tapas, main and a dessert all for under 50 euros, so excellent value for the quality and service we received. We can't comment on drinks because we only had water due to our early flight the next morning but the free liquer to end on was much appreciated.One of the best dining experiences we have had, please go here.....you won't regret it!

We had a great time at Taberna Mas Al Sur and it is a definite go to place while in Madrid.

Gambas was also a great dish to taste good quality shrimp. 이 곳을 방문했을 때 독감으로 한 창 고생할 때라 몸 상태가 말이 아니였다. 원래 술을 좋아하는 나였지만 이 날 만큼은 안먹을 생각이었으나, Edu의 감바스에 마실 것 하나 하는 게 좋지않겠냐는 말에 그럴 것 같아서 무난해보이는 모히또를 주문했었다. 모히또는 정말 맛있었지만 생각보다 도수가 쎈 탓에 2모금 정도 마셨나? 이후 손도 못대고 있었더니 그걸 본 Edu가 자신이 만든 모히또가 맛없냐고 물어왔고, 사정을 설명해줬다. 다 듣고 난 Edu는 되려 자신이 미안하다며 다른 술로 바꿔주겠다고 했고 나는 추천을 해달랬더니 샹그리아를 추천해주더라. 아니 방금 술 많이 못마실 것 같은 상태랬는데 뭐지 싶었으나 Edu는 샹그리아가 매우 약한 술이니 괜찮을거랬고 난 믿어보기로했다. 잠시 후 나온 샹그리아는 보기도 너무 이쁘게 데코돼있었고, 술이 약한 걸 감안해 일부러 그렇게 제조한 건지 원래 그렇게 나오는 건지 모르겠으나 오렌지주스를 반 섞어서 알콜 도수가 거의 안느껴질정도로 제조해주었다. 결과적으로 이 곳은 칵테일이 정말 끝내주고 데코도 너무 이쁘며 같이 먹은 감바스는 조금 짜지만 함께 나온 빵과 함께 먹으니 간이 잘 맞았고 새우의 질이 매우 좋아 그 탱글한 식감이 매우 감동적이었다. 그리고 이 모든 것들에 최고의 서비스가 곁들여져 그저 길 가다 들린 사람에게도 기분좋은 식사 시간을 선물해준다. 위치는 소피아 여왕 국립미술관 근처라 그 일정있는 날 들리면 좋을 것 같다.

Unfortunately on the day of our visit my wife was just recovering from her stomach illness, and she was only able to nibble food. The restaurant has nice basement premises for dinner customers.  As a starter I decided to order something small – so I ordered Grilled Goat Cheese Salad over Fresh Apple Jam. The salad was tasty, but absolutely oversized for one person. Even for two persons it might be a decent challenge.  My mains - Acorn Fed 100% Iberian Grilled with Natural Carbon was also delicious but also too big. Luckily my dessert - Chocolate Mousse with Almonds Crisp and Pistachio Ice Cream - was of reasonable size. As a digestive I ordered coffee with brandy. Unfortunately the warm-up process of the brandy glass took so long that when it finally arrived I had finished my coffee. So I was alone with my (plentiful amount of) brandy.   Our special thanks to our waiter Roberto, who was very professional with his recommendations. The service as a whole, however suffered from slight slowness.

review_full: Had attempted to visit another local favorite (Hermanos Valdivieso) which was closed due to August holiday and pleasantly stumbled into this local gem. Located right near the Reina Sofia and it's bar/hostel district, the unassuming storefront does not prepare you for the quality experience we received. All dishes were brought out as they were ready and were executed perfectly. The ropa vieja was delightfully flavorful and the rollito de pollo was perfectly tender, while the risottos maintained their parmesan-y strength until the very last bite. Jonny was pleasant and engaging and ensured that we did not over order, which surprised in this heavily touristy area. Would recommend, and will return.

title_review: Worthwhile and delicious, cookery at its best.
review_preview: A tiny number of tables ensures that the dance of the service is impeccable. From the reception and choice of menu guided by Ramon in person, to the petit fours.I have been to many Michelin starred restaurants and I come from the place in...
review_full: A tiny number of tables ensures that the dance of the service is impeccable. From the reception and choice of menu guided by Ramon in person, to the petit fours. I have been to many Michelin starred restaurants and I come from the place in the world with the highest ratio per person, still sometimes it is not what you would expect. In this case, the food was all surprising and delicious, special mention to the cooked cheeses, an original and delightful deviation from the traditional French cheese platter. Desserts were marvellous too, I suggest to skip the bread to be able to fit it all! Excellent wine choices. The highs and lows of the menu: The fish was very well prepared but the type of fish chosen happens to be my least favourite so that was a bit of a shame. Some of the food explanations are said so quickly that is hard to follow. The bread was the only questionable thing we were served. On one hand, the butter bread, a brioche style bread was delicious, but really heavy and probably more appropriate for a breakfast than for a dinner that has 7 dishes after it (after the bread) the other types of bread were really average and not at the level of the rest of the food. Anyway, it is honestly not a problem. Anyway I would probably recommend not to eat it at all to be able to enjoy all the lovely dishes.
